{{Infobox person | name = Gergely Böszörményi-Nagy | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Gergely Böszörményi-Nagy | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|08|01|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Budapest, Hungary]] | residence = [[Budapest, Hungary]] | nationality = Hungarian | alma_mater = [[Corvinus University of Budapest]] [[Central European University]] [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]] | occupation = [[entrepreneur]] | known_for = Founder of Brain Bar | title = Executive Director of Design Terminal }}
'''Gergely Böszörményi-Nagy''' (born August 1, 1984) is an entrepreneur and former public servant who founded [[Brain Bar]].
Böszörményi-Nagy is also executive director of [[:hu:Design Terminál|Design Terminal]], a private business based in [[Budapest, Hungary]] that helps startups to reach the global marketplace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ne100.org/challenger/gergely-boszormenyi-nagy,5654f734de187a962c0a5e91|title=ne100|website=ne100.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref>
==[https://444.hu/2015/08/19/alig-volt-ember-aki-jegyet-vett-az-allami-inspiracios-fesztivalra Education]== Böszörményi-Nagy studied [[International relations]] at [[Corvinus University of Budapest]]. He pursued a [[Master of Business Administration]] at [[Central European University]] and participated at the Executive Program in [[Social entrepreneurship|Social Entrepreneurship]] of [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]].
==Career== From 2010 to 2012, Böszörményi-Nagy was deputy head of strategic communication for the [[Government of Hungary]]. Among other campaigns, he led the public outreach of [[Hungary]]'s first [[Presidency of the Council of the European Union]].
In 2012 Böszörményi-Nagy joined Design Terminal, the government agency responsible for design and innovation as strategic director, where he was subsequently promoted to general director in January, 2014. During his leadership, the company launched an extensive portfolio of early stage, non-equity incubation services for innovative enterprises, for which Design Terminal was awarded the European Enterprise Promotion Awards by the [[European Commission]] in 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/growth/smes/support/enterprise-promotion-awards_hu |title=European Enterprise Promotion Awards - European Commission |language=hu|website=Ec.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref> and was also named the "best startup accelerator in Hungary" two years later.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.uzletresz.hu/vallalkozas/20161028-a-kozep-europai-startup-verseny-hazai-dontojen-a-design-terminalt-valasztottak-a-legjobb.html |title=A Design Terminαl a legjobb magyar inkubαtor |website=Uzletresz.hu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref> In 2015, [[UNESCO]] selected Budapest for its global [[Creative Cities]] network,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calvertjournal.com/news/show/5223/budapest-and-kaunas-awarded-title-city-of-design-by-unesco |title=Budapest and Kaunas awarded title "City of Design" by UNESCO — The Calvert Journal |website=Calvertjournal.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref> mostly in recognition of the [http://welovebudapest.com/budapest.and.hungary/unesco.honors.budapest.as.one.of.the.world.s.most.creative.cities services and projects of Design Terminal].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://welovebudapest.com/budapest.and.hungary/unesco.honors.budapest.as.one.of.the.world.s.most.creative.cities|title=UNESCO honors Budapest as one of the world’s most creative cities {{!}} WeLoveBudapest.com|website=welovebudapest.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-04}}</ref> In 2016, Böszörményi-Nagy and his team was appointed to prepare the country's official startup strategy, the government's legislative package to stimulate the innovation ecosystem by incentives for entrepreneurial education, business incubation and angel investment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://figyelo.hu/cikkek/441739-viragzo-startup-fovarossa-valhat-budapest |title=Figyelő online |StartUp + KKV | Virágzó startup fővárossá válhat Budapest |website=Figyelo.hu |date=2016-12-29 |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref> Later in 2016, following a general restructuring in the Hungarian public administration, Design Terminal made a transition to the private sector, and continues its operations as an independent nonprofit that relies mostly on financing from the Hungarian government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://designterminal.hu/news/design-terminal-to-become-an-independent-nonprofit_184 |title=Design Terminal to become an independent nonprofit | Design Terminál |language=hu|website=Designterminal.hu |date=2016-09-01 |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref>
==Brain Bar== In June, 2015 Böszörményi-Nagy founded [[Brain Bar]], a global festival focused on the future.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/brain-bar-budapest-a-clash-of-ideas-in-the-heart-of-europe|title=Brain Bar Budapest: a clash of ideas in the heart of Europe|last=Insider|first=WIRED|work=WIRED UK|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-GB}}</ref> The annual event revolves around a two-day concentration of talks and debates on business, social, cultural, technological and political trends<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/brain-bar-dangerous-ideas-welcome|title=Brain Bar: Dangerous ideas welcome|last=|first=|date=|work=WIRED UK|access-date=2018-05-05}}</ref>, and attracts thousands of visitors per year with past speakers including [[PayPal]] co-founder [[Peter Thiel]], historian [[Niall Ferguson]], three Michelin star restaurateur [[Massimo Bottura]], [[WPP plc]] founder [[Sir Martin Sorrell]], EU Commissioner for Competition [[Margrethe Vestager]], best-selling futurist [[Kevin Kelly (editor)|Kevin Kelly]], [[The Pirate Bay|Pirate Bay]] founder [[Peter Sunde]], geopolitical analyst [[George Friedman]], sociologist [[Philip Zimbardo]], astronaut and former [[International Space Station]] commander [[Chris Hadfield]] and the world's first humanoid robot citizen, [[Sophia (robot)|Sophia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bigthink.com/design-for-good/europes-biggest-festival-on-the-future-will-gather-top-scientists-artists-and-entrepreneurs|title=Brain Bar Budapest: Top Scientists, Artists, Entrepreneurs|last=Zareva|first=Teodora|work=Big Think|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bbj.hu/budapest/brain-bar-budapest-to-welcome-experts_97848|title=Brain Bar Budapest to welcome experts|work=Budapest Business Journal|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.origo.hu/itthon/20170608-telthazas-volt-a-harmadik-brain-bar-budapest-jovofesztival.html|title=Kiderült, mi lesz velünk a jövőben|last=Origo|work=origo.hu/|access-date=2017-07-11|language=hu}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@brainbarbudapest/the-brain-behind-brain-bar-q-a-with-gergely-b%C3%B6sz%C3%B6rm%C3%A9nyi-4c1acba7943b|title=The Brain Behind Brain Bar: Q&A with the Co-Founder|last=Budapest|first=Brain Bar|date=2016-04-22|website=Medium|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://futurism.com/time-travel-bend-time/|title=We can't alter the course of time but, according to physics, we can bend it|date=2017-10-31|work=Futurism|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://futurism.com/cern-scientist-on-life-after-the-higgs-boson/|title=CERN scientist on life after the higgs boson|date=2017-10-24|work=Futurism|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://futurism.com/ubi-universal-basic-income-alternative/|title=Experts May Have a Viable Alternative to Universal Basic Income|date=2017-11-08|work=Futurism|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/eu/2018/06/02/now-is-the-time-for-citizens-to-take-control/|title=EU commissioner Margrethe Vestager: ‘Now is the time for citizens to take control’|last=Maack|first=Már Másson|date=2018-06-02|work=The Next Web|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://forbes.hu/uzlet/brain-bar-peter-thiel/|title=Peter Thiel, a Szilícium-völgy ellentmondásos zsenije Budapestre jön {{!}} Forbes.hu|website=forbes.hu|language=hu|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://forbes.hu/a-jo-elet/a-vilag-legnepszerubb-sefje-ha-nem-fejlodnek-abbahagynam-a-fozest/|title=A világ legnépszerűbb séfje: Ha nem fejlődnék, abbahagynám a főzést {{!}} Forbes.hu|website=forbes.hu|language=hu|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> In its fourth year of operation, with [[Wired (magazine)|WIRED]] as media partner <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/brain-bar-dangerous-ideas-welcome|title=Brain Bar: Dangerous ideas welcome|last=Insider|first=WIRED|date=|work=WIRED UK|access-date=25 April 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>, Brain Bar's strategic partners include [[Magyar Telekom]], [[MOL (company)|MOL]], [[BMW]], and [[KPMG]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bbj.hu/promotion/brain-bar-budapest-welcomes-kpmg-as-main-sponsor_132461|title=Brain Bar Budapest welcomes KPMG as main sponsor|work=Budapest Business Journal|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kreativ.hu/cikk/globalis_nagyagyuk_is_jonnek_a_brain_bar_budapestre|title=Kreatív Online - Globális nagyágyúk is jönnek a Brain Bar Budapestre|work=Kreatív Online|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref> As part of its social impact policy, Brain Bar is free to attend for a group of outstanding teachers and students based on pre-selection.
'''Criticism'''
Many critics note that Brain Bar, not unlike Design Terminal is mostly using public money ([https://444.hu/2015/08/19/alig-volt-ember-aki-jegyet-vett-az-allami-inspiracios-fesztivalra 100 million HUF in 2015] ) for a festival that attracts very few people outside of the organizers' circles (in the same year, 2015 only 143 tickets were actually sold). The money is mostly spent on star performers who, even unwittingly legitimate officials of the Hungarian right-wing government like the unorthodox president of the Hungarian national Bank, Gyorgy Matolcsy.
==Awards== In 2014, the Hungarian edition of [[Forbes]] named Böszörményi-Nagy in its '30 under 30' list of successful young leaders,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://forbes.hu/esemenyek/forbes-flow/30-30-csucstalalkozo |title=Forbes Flow - 30/30 csúcstalálkozó - Forbes Magyarország |website=Forbes.hu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref> and [[Google]], the ''[[Financial Times]]'' and the [[International Visegrad Fund]] named Böszörményi-Nagy among the 'New Europe 100', a list of Central Europe's key figures in the digital economy.<ref>{{cite web|author=hvg.hu |url=http://hvg.hu/kkv/20141002_Ok_a_magyar_innovacio_moguljai |title=Vállalkozás: Ők a magyar innováció moguljai |website=HVG.hu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{external links|date=January 2017}} * [http://visegradinsight.eu/promoting-intellectual-capital-from-central-europe/ Promoting intellectual capital from Central Europe], Visegrad Insight (2016). * [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tom-j-hidvegi/budapest-tech-startups-and-innovation_b_4363471.html Hungry for Innovation: Budapest is a New Terminal for Startups], [[The Huffington Post]] (2013).

{{Infobox person | name = | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1845|06|27}} | birth_place = [[Mannheim]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1905|04|08|1845|06|27}}
| death_place = [[Munich]] | resting_place = 5 - 5 – 56 [[Alter Südfriedhof]] | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | spouse = [[Bachelor]] | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = Gottfried Höch (1800-1872), the economist managed the estates of [[Stéphanie de Beauharnais]]. | relatives = | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = Real Estate Tycoon in Munich | notable_works = }} '''Heinrich Theodor Höch''' was a German businessman.
Höch grew up in [[Ludwigshafen]], then part of the [[Kingdom of Bavaria]], where his father [[Gottfried Höch]] was the [[Éminence grise]] in the founding of the community of Ludwigshafen. In 1864, at the age of 19, he began his first venture, which was to export "Palatine tobacco" to the [[Union (American Civil War)|United States of America]] during the [[American Civil War]]. The end of the war led to his first bankruptcy, but he continued in trading with goods and acted as a broker.
He entered the rail industry in the 1860s, participating as a co-accordant in the construction of the [[Munich–Rosenheim railway]] line. The fast-growing railway network had doubled in size in Bavaria, and led to an expansion of the local networks. Höch's businesses were successful in this era. In 1866, he moved to [[Munich]], where he dedicated himself to general trade and finance, from [[suspenders]] and walking sticks to investments in the real estate business. == Realising the grid plan in Maxvorstadt== *Höch's projects show an integral understanding of the needs of urban housing and that he partly managed to maintain the projects till their [[Break-even (economics)]]. *[[Hippodamus of Miletus]] recommended the [[Grid plan]]. *During a study trip through the Netherlands, [[Frederick IV, Elector Palatine]] got to know the progress of Dutch fortification architecture; he decided on the plans of an engineer celebrity, Johann von Rijswijk for Friedrichsburg ([[Mannheim]]) *From {{dts|1606|06|18}} to 1610 the Dutch hydraulic engineer, Bartholomäus Janson realized the Grid plan in Mannheim. *With [[Maximilian III Joseph, Elector of Bavaria]], the Bavarian line of Wittelsbacher died in 1777. It followed with [[Charles Theodore, Elector of Bavaria]] the line Pfalz-Sulzbach, which already ruled over the Electoral Palatinate. After the death of Karl Theodor in 1799, the Dukes of Zweibrücken obtained the title of Elector. *In 1810 an architect, also born in Mannheim, [[Karl von Fischer]] designed a [[Grid plan]] as structure for the [[Maxvorstadt]]. *After the {{Ill|Erste Allgemeine Deutsche Industrieausstellung|de}} and the [[Cholera]] of 1854 this new part of Munich was built with [[storm drains]] in every street. *As a land owner, Heinrich Theodor Höch could not compete with the Breweries and the [[Catholic Church]] in Munich in this [[Monopoly (game)]]. To convince investors in his projects he gave attention to [[Public relations]]. *In 1886 [[Schwabing]] got city rights and on 20 November 1890 it was incorporated to Munich. In the meantime it was a [[Boomtown]] compared with [[Munich]]. On {{dts|1889|02|26}} Schwabing got electric street lighting, while in Munich gas lanterns still glowed, since then its common [[Marketing]] to sell residences in [[Maxvorstadt]] as Quasi-Schwabing. *Over the years, Höch had built entire streets. He was particularly involved in the emergence of the artists' quarter in the [[Maxvorstadt|new Schwabing]], which could not be wrongly called a Schwabing Höchs, and large sections of the extensive, west of it located between Schwabingerlandstraße (today's [[Leopoldstraße]]) and [[Schleißheimer Straße (Munich)]]. *As the center of the artistic condominium he donated the space for the construction of the new {{Ill|St. Ursula (München)|de}}, built by {{Ill|August Thiersch|de}} between 1894 and 1897. *After the [[Panic of 1873]], at the end of the seventies Höch started his first big venture. He built the entire Heßstraße, where he lived at this time in No. 46. Without his fault, he came here in great distress. A neighboring house collapsed, causing the entire area to be discredited for five to six years as a neighborhood of dodgy buildings. At the foreclosure sale of about 40 properties, Höch's debts amounted to more than one million. He went bankrupt.<ref>On {{dts|1938|01|18}} [[Hans Beilhack]] dedicated an article to Höch in the ''Münchner Zeitung'' with the [[Headline]]: The man who changed the face of Munich. On 22 May 1938 [[Adolf Hitler]] did the first cut of the spade for a tunnel that forty years later became the [[Goetheplatz (Munich U-Bahn)]] as the first step of the [[Bombing of Munich in World War II|Gesamtbauplan für die Hauptstadt der Bewegung]]. Beilhack, already banned from writing, showed the narrow degree between visionary investor and impostor.</ref> ==Dairy farm== In 1875, Höch had the idea of opening a dairy farm in the Heßstraße, which was still undeveloped at the time. For that dairy farm, he bought the first four of twenty cows. There was also produced [[Pasteurization|child milk]], a novelty found by [[Franz von Soxhlet]]. In 1877, Höch acquired the right of home and [[Citizenship]] in Munich for 171 marks, the German currency used in that time, which equals around $2000 nowadays.
==Volksgarten Nymphenburg== In 1890, he founded and financed the {{Ill|Volksgarten Nymphenburg|de}} with {{Ill|Hugo Oertel|de}}.
==Project Tuberculosis spa cure== Already in 1891, a side from playing [[Hide-and-seek]] with his [[Creditor]]s he dedicated to the theme of [[Tuberculosis]], Höch pursued a new plan with the acquisition of Palais Gumpenberg on Ottostraße 6. Here, according to his will, a spa cure for pulmonary patients should arise, which should be helped by using the healing serum developed by [[Robert Koch]]. However, since the idea failed because of the resistance of the residents, in 1892 it became the "Hotel Continental", where [[Rainer Maria Rilke]] later descended during his stays in Munich.
==Project Septic drain fields in Großlappen== With an astonishing foresight, in the north of Munich at Großlappen, Höch planned the planting of [[Septic drain field]]s, for which he had already secured reasons.
==Investments== Höch acquired extensive land in parts of Munich like [[Nymphenburg]], Obersendling and Menzing. He had a copper mine in the Rhön arise and even acquired plantations overseas. He also funded balloon projects, founded magazines and a shoe factory.
== Project Industrial district Freimann== Höch tried to establish an industrial district in Freimann. Following the pattern of [[Heilmann & Littmann]]'s Industrieviertel on the [[Sendling]]er Oberfeld, he planned the construction of an industrial district, which was to develop in northern Schwabing in the direction of {{ill|Freimann, Munich|lt=Freimann|de|Freimann}}. For this he had already acquired 1000 {{Ill|Tagewerk|de}} reason. But again, the tide should turn. Opposed authorities but also practices of bad business colleagues and his own plans, which did not keep pace with reality, ruined him again. At this point in time, half pages with the [[Court auction]] announcements often appeared in announcements of {{Ill|Münchner Neueste Nachrichten|de}}.
==Third and last bankruptcy== Finally, in 1904, Höch's empire broke, which greatly boosted the city's economy. It was Höch's third and last bankruptcy, and at the same time the largest bankruptcy in Munich, when it came to 428 appointments in front of the Chamber of Commerce.
Höch was summoned by a creditor consortium for declaring the state of being bankrupt. He had to confess that he was in need of a spinal cord condition and that he had been unable to give exhaustive information about his entire estate, which was also accepted as credible.
The last photographic portrait shows a man already affected by the illness, whose eyes look tired and inward.Heinrich Theodor Höch, at that time Munich's most daring entrepreneur in terms of construction and land speculation, died as a bachelor a year after the third economic collapse on April 8, 1905 in his last apartment on Franz Josef Straße 27. <ref>[[Gerhard J. Bellinger]], {{Ill|Brigitte Regler-Bellinger|de}}, Schwabings Ainmillerstraße und ihre bedeutendsten Anwohner: Ein repräsentatives Beispiel der Münchner Stadtgeschichte von 1888 bis heute [https://books.google.de/books?id=-9DqGDpI5OkC&pg=PA368&dq=Hans+Beilhack+1898&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi9-svOuNnXAhVCDsAKHVJUCQAQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Hans%20Beilhack%201898&f=false p. 368][https://books.google.de/books?id=lfQbAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT338&dq=H%C3%B6ch+Tabak+%C3%9Cbersee&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPnsLsyuXXAhVeGsAKHRIdCjoQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=H%C3%B6ch%20Tabak%20%C3%9Cbersee&f=false p. 369][https://books.google.de/books?id=lfQbAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT341&dq=%22Ein+eindrucksvolles+Beispiel+solcher+Transaktionen%22&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjiq6mU_OfXAhVLzqQKHYLIAG0Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22Ein%20eindrucksvolles%20Beispiel%20solcher%20Transaktionen%22&f=false p. 372][https://books.google.de/books?id=-9DqGDpI5OkC&pg=PA374&dq=%22Das+war+sein+Lebensinhalt.+CARL%22&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjZ6-qdue7XAhVPKuwKHVEMA34Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=%22Das%20war%20sein%20Lebensinhalt.%20CARL%22&f=false p. 374]</ref>

{{Primary sources|date=May 2009}} {{Infobox organization | name = International Business Wales | image = IBW logo small.jpg | formation = 2006 | status = Development Agency | headquarters = | region_served = [[Wales]] | leader_title = Director | leader_name = Ian Williams | budget = | website = [http://www.ibwales.com/ ibwales.com] | remarks = Appointment: [[Welsh Government]] }}
'''International Business Wales''' (IBW) is a development agency of the [[Welsh Government]] set up with the remit of delivering support to help companies establish themselves in [[Wales]]. Once established in the country, companies are allocated a Relationship Manager with the skills to help grow the business and are offered a relocation service that helps their executives settle there.
==IBW Structure== IBW provide the trade and investment arm of the Welsh Government. Established in 2006, it brought together the responsibilities of the former [[Welsh Development Agency]] and Wales Trade International.
Sitting under the [https://web.archive.org/web/20060514103255/http://new.wales.gov.uk/about/departments/dein/?lang=en Department for the Economy and Transport (DE&T)] IBW is tasked with developing international trade, and attracting [[inward investment]], relocation and international collaboration.
==Track record== IBW claims it has an impressive track record with Wales being one of Europe’s most successful investment locations. With a population of 2.9 million and a workforce of 1.3 million, Wales has attracted over £16.8 billion of capital investment and over 282,000 jobs have been created or safeguarded through inward investment (between 1983 and March 2008).
Over 500 international companies are located in the country including many of the world’s largest multinationals such as [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], [[Electronic Data Systems|EDS]] and [[Alcatel-Lucent|Alcatel]].
==Area covered== IBW offer support to companies looking at Wales as a business destination for expansion/relocation as well as supporting the companies located in the country with their international trade requirements. *Inward Investment - project management support to advise companies on all aspects of relocation from grants and skilled workforce availability through to property searches and a relocation service for business people under the “Welcome to Wales” programme. *International Trade - services for both native Welsh companies and international business looking for a trade partner in Wales, with support from advisors. IBW provide support tailored to company import and export needs.
==Criticism== In July 2009, using information obtained from a Freedom of Information request to the Welsh government, the [[Welsh Liberal Democrats]] criticised International Business Wales officials for running up a bill of £750,000, on 35 different corporate credit card accounts for the year June 2008 to end of May 2009, at the tax-payers expense. Liberal Democrat leader [[Kirsty Williams]] AM said: :"In the middle of a recession it's disgusting to know that public officials are flying first class, staying in the most expensive hotels, eating in the best restaurants - all at the swipe of the Welsh credit card."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/wales_politics/8148458.stm BBC Wales News: "Civil servants' £750k cards bill" 13.07.09]</ref>
First Minister [[Rhodri Morgan]] at first refuted the allegation. He later publicly apologised in a letter to Kirsty Williams and said that he had been misled by IBW officials, whom he had believed at the time: :"I stated, on the clear and explicit advice from the relevant senior officials that no officials from IBW (International Business Wales) had flown first class. Today I have learned that this is not the case. I apologise for having misled you and the wider public."<ref name=letter>BBC Wales: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/betsanpowys/2009/07/im_sorry.html Letter from First Minister Rhodri Morgan to Kirsty Williams AM], 15 August 2009.</ref>
He added that he was setting up an investigation and independent review: :"I need hardly say how disturbed I am by this latest information now to hand. I am instructing the Permanent Secretary to undertake an immediate and thorough investigation and audit of IBW's expenditure and audit systems. This review will be led from outside the Assembly Government."<ref name=letter />
==Support== Following the July 2009 press coverage a group of Welsh exporters have shown their support for International Business Wales, calling on politicians to "stop playing politics" with the organisation. Malcolm Duncan, Managing Director of Blaenavon-based Super Rod, who heads up the support group said: :"I understand the need for the public to be kept informed about the activities of any Government department. But what does worry me is when politicians start to play politics with these departments, that could ultimately have a detrimental effect on both business and our economy as a whole."<ref>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/business-in-wales/business-news/2009/08/15/exporters-reject-attack-on-ibw-91466-24446015/ Wales Online: "Exporters reject attack on IBW" 15.08.09]</ref>
=="Economic Renewal: a new direction"== On Monday 5 July 2010 the [[Welsh Assembly Government]] announced plans to transform the way it supports businesses and the Welsh economy. "Economic Renewal: a new direction" is a vision to make Wales "one of the best places in the world to live, to work and to thrive".
As part of the transformation, functions previously supported by International Business Wales, Trade and Inward investment, can be accessed directly through the Welsh Government; or by [http://www.ibwales.com visiting the Trade and Inward investment website] or calling (+44) 1443 845500.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.ibwales.com/ International Business Wales] * [http://www.ibwales.in/ International Business Wales - India] * [http://www.visitwales.com/ Visit Wales] * [http://www.wales.gov.uk/business/ Welsh Government] * [http://www.walesworldnation.com/server.php?show=nav.5889 Business in Wales] * [http://media.ft.com/cms/659b223a-69db-11de-bc9f-00144feabdc0.pdf Doing Business in Cardiff and Wales supplement], ''Financial Times'', Tuesday July 7 2009] *[https://www.cnbc.com/id/31268765 Washington Trade Mission] - CNBC News story about IBW supporting over 80 Welsh companies to establish business links with major U.S. companies such as [[Boeing]] and [[NASA]].

Chandris | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year|1890}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death year and age|1942|1890}} | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation =[[shipowner]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | children = [[Dimitri Chandris]]
Anthony Chandris }} '''John D. Chandris''' (1890 – 1942) was a [[Greece|Greek]] shipowner. Chandris was born in [[Chios]], then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In 1915, after years of experience in the shipping industry, he bought his first ship, the S/S ''Dimitrios''.{{cite web|title=6 Cruise Industry Pioneers|url=http://www.travelpulse.com/news/features/6-cruise-industry-pioneers.html|website=Travel Pulse|accessdate=18 April 2017}} By [[World War I]], Chandris' fleet was made up of four ships, including [[steamship]]s.{{cite web|title=6 Cruise Industry Pioneers|url=http://www.travelpulse.com/news/features/6-cruise-industry-pioneers.html|website=Travel Pulse|accessdate=18 April 2017}} In 1922, he expanded into the passenger shipping market. Following the outbreak of [[World War II]], Chandris followed the exodus of shipowners from Greece. He moved to England. Chandris ran the cruise lines until he retired in 1939. He died in 1942 at the age 52 from natural causes. His two sons, [[Anthony J. Chandris|Anthony]] and [[Dimitri Chandris|Dimitri]], later rebuilt the company, named [[Chandris Line]].{{cite web|title=Greek Shipping Hall of Fame: ANTHONY J. CHANDRIS (1924-1984)|url=http://greekshippinghalloffame.org/chandris.html|website=greekshippinghalloffame.org|accessdate=8 June 2017}} A partnership called Chandris-Fantasy Cruises started in the early 1980s and later was divided into two separate arms, Fantasy-Cruises and Celebrity cruises. ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chandris, John}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:People from Chios]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in England]] {{Greece-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Sir Leonard Blavatnik | image = Leonard Blavatnik, February 2018 (4568) (cropped).jpg | birth_date = {{birth_date and age|1957|6|14|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Odessa]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[London]], [[England]], UK | nationality = | citizenship = United Kingdom-United States{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/len-blavatnik/?list=billionaires|title=Len Blavatnik|work=forbes.com|accessdate=17 January 2017}}
| education = [[Moscow State University of Railway Engineering]]
[[Columbia University]] (M.S.)
[[Harvard Business School]] (M.B.A.) | occupation = Founder of [[Access Industries]] | religion = | children = 4 | website = | imagesize = | spouse = Emily Appelson | networth = {{increase}} US$20.1 billion (2017)[https://www.forbes.com/profile/len-blavatnik Len Blavatnik]; accessed June 14, 2017. }} '''Sir Leonard "Len" Blavatnik''' ({{lang-ua|Леонід Валентинович Блаватнік}}, {{lang-ru|Леонид Валентинович Блаватник}}, ''Leonid Valentinovich Blavatnik''; born June 14, 1957) is a Soviet-born British-American businessman, investor, and philanthropist. He made his fortune through business via diversified investments in myriad companies through his conglomerate company, [[Access Industries]]. As of January 2018, Blavatnik was the wealthiest man in the [[United Kingdom]], and the 50th wealthiest in the world, with a net worth of US$21.2 billion.{{cite news|title=Music boss Len Blavatnik named as Britain's richest man|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-32464402|publisher=BBC News | date=April 26, 2015}} In 2017, Blavatnik received a [[Knight Bachelor|knighthood]] for services to philanthropy. ==Early life and education== Blavatnik was born in [[Odessa]], [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Ukraine]], to a [[Jewish]] family.[http://www.haaretz.com/news/russian-born-u-s-billionaire-offers-to-buy-ma-ariv-1.249288 "Russian-born U.S. billionaire offers to buy Ma'ariv"], haaretz.com; accessed February 23, 2015.[http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishFeatures/Article.aspx?id=187418 "The world's 50 Richest Jews: 11-20: Len Blavatnik"], jpost.com, September 7, 2010. He attended [[Moscow State University of Railway Engineering]], but did not complete his coursework due to the family's request for emigration visas. His family emigrated from the [[Soviet Union]] to the United States in 1978, and he received a masters in computer science from [[Columbia University]] and an [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]] in 1989.[https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2011/05/05/warner-music-suitors-record-of-deal-making/?nl=business&emc=dlbkpma1 "Warner Music Suitor’s Record of Deal-Making"]. Ben Protess. ''DealBook''. May 5, 2011 ==Career== In 1986, Blavatnik founded Access Industries, an international conglomerate company located in New York, of which he is chairman and president. Access has long-term holdings in Europe and North and South America. Initially, he moved into Russian investments, just after the fall of communism. He and a friend from university, [[Viktor Vekselberg]], formed the Renova investment vehicle, and then the two joined with [[Mikhail Fridman]]'s [[Alfa Group]] to form the AAR venture.Yenikeyeff, Shamil, [http://www.oxfordenergy.org/wpcms/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/BP-Russian-billionaires-and-the-Kremlin.pdf "BP, Russian billionaires, and the Kremlin: a Power Triangle that never was"], ''Oxford Energy Comment'', November 23, 2011; retrieved March 3, 2015. Access has since diversified its portfolio to include investments in industries such as oil, entertainment, coal, aluminum, petrochemicals and plastics, telecommunications, media, and real estate. {{citation needed|date=February 2015}} ===Petrochemicals and oil=== In August 2005, [[Access Industries]] bought petrochemicals and plastics manufacturer [[Basell Polyolefins]] from [[Royal Dutch Shell]] and [[BASF]] for $5.7 billion. On December 20, 2007, Basell completed its acquisition of the [[Lyondell Chemical Company]] for an enterprise value of approximately $19 billion. The resulting company, [[LyondellBasell]] Industries then became the world's eighth largest chemical company based on net sales.{{cite web|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/92/i30/CENs-Global-Top-50-Chemical.html|title=C&EN’s Global Top 50 Chemical Firms For 2014|publisher=[[Chemical & Engineering News]]|accessdate=August 20, 2014}} On January 6, 2009, the U.S. operations of LyondellBasell Industries filed for bankruptcy.[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/02/business/02chemical.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=blavatnik&st=cse LyondellBasell May Seek Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection], nytimes.com; accessed February 23, 2015. On April 30, 2010, LyondellBasell emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in a significantly improved financial position. As part of its exit financing, LyondellBasell raised $3.25 billion of first priority debt as well as $2.8 billion through the rights offering jointly underwritten by Access Industries, [[Apollo Management]], and [[Ares Management]].[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN3018504120100430 LyondellBasell profile]; accessed February 23, 2015. LyondellBasell stock has increased 103% in value since April 2010. Access currently owns approximately 14% of LyondellBasell. AAR gained a controlling stake in Russian oil company TNK through [[privatization]] auctions, then in 2003 sold a 50% stake to [[British Petroleum]] to form [[TNK-BP]], one of Russia's largest oil companies, where Blavatnik served on the board of directors. On March 21, 2013, Rosneft completed its $55 billion acquisition of TNK-BP. Blavatnik also has interests in [[UC Rusal]], the world's largest aluminum producer, where he sits on the board. On May 6, 2011, Warner Music Group announced its sale to Access for US$3.3 billion.Wilkerson, David B., [http://www.marketwatch.com/story/warner-music-to-be-sold-in-33-billion-cash-deal-2011-05-06 "Warner Music to be sold in $3.3 billion cash deal"], ''[[MarketWatch]]'', May 6, 2011; retrieved 2011-05-06. ===Finance=== In 2010, Blavatnik sued [[JPMorgan Chase]] after losing $100 million by allegedly following Morgan's advice three years earlier to buy mortgage securities with AAA [[credit rating]]s.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/25/business/25nocera.html?_r=1&hp Lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase], nytimes.com; accessed February 23, 2015. JPMorgan Chase was ordered to pay $50 million to Blavatnik on August 27, 2013.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-23845347 JPMorgan Chase ordered to pay Blavatnik $50 million in damages], bbc.co.uk; accessed February 23, 2015. ===Entertainment=== In early 2010, Access Industries was reported as one of the handful of bidders for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a0z_Wp9izMUM MGM bidding by Access Industries], bloomberg.com; accessed February 23, 2015. On July 20, 2011, an Access affiliate acquired Warner Music Group for $3.3 billion. {{Cite news|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2011/05/06/warner-music-to-sell-itself-to-access-for-3-3-billion/|title=Warner Music Is Sold, Ending a Long Auction|last=Sisario|first=Michael J. de la Merced and Ben|work=DealBook|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en}}{{Cite web|title = Access Industries buys Warner Music Group for $3.3bn - Music Business Worldwide|url = http://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/access-industries-buys-warner-music-group-for-3-3bn/|website = Music Business Worldwide|access-date = 2016-01-28|language = en-US}} In 2016, Blavatnik launched Access Entertainment, which bought James Packer's stake in RatPac Entertainment and a 24.9% stake in Bad Wolf in 2017{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/global/len-blavatnik-danny-cohen-access-bad-wolf-1202016848/|title=Len Blavatnik, Danny Cohen’s Access Entertainment Backs Bad Wolf (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Barraclough|first=Leo|date=2017-03-27|work=Variety|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/james-packer-has-sold-his-stake-in-hollywood-film-company-ratpac-entertainment-2017-4|title=James Packer has sold his stake in Hollywood film company RatPac Entertainment|last=Thomsen|first=Simon|date=2017-04-20|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en}}. In April 2018, it was reported that Blavatnik was a front runner in the bidding to purchase Britain’s third oldest theatre, the Theatre Royal Haymarket. Sources report that the bid is around £40 million{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/billionaire-blavatnik-leads-race-to-buy-prized-west-end-theatre-11348588|title=Billionaire Blavatnik leads race to buy prized West End theatre|work=Sky News|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-GB}} Blavatnik also owns AI Film, the independent film and production company which backed [[Lee Daniels]]’ film ''[[The Butler]]'' and the summer 2015 release ''Mr. Holmes''.{{Cite web|title = Blavatnik owns AI Film, the independent film and production company that’s behind acclaimed film Lee Daniels’ The Butler and the summer 2015 release Mr. Holmes.|url = http://www.businessinsider.in/meet-len-blavatnik-the-richest-man-in-britain/Blavatnik-owns-AI-Film-the-independent-film-and-production-company-thats-behind-acclaimed-film-Lee-Daniels-The-Butler-and-the-summer-2015-release-Mr-Holmes-/slideshow/47790832.cms?from=mdr|website = Business Insider|access-date = 2016-01-28}} He was an early investor in Rocket Internet and Beats Music, helped finance fashion designer Tory Burch, and in 2013 paid $115 million for wireless spectrum in Norway.{{Cite web|title = Len Blavatnik|url = https://www.forbes.com/profile/len-blavatnik/|website = Forbes|access-date = 2016-01-28}} ===Board membership=== Blavatnik is a member of the Global Advisory Board of the Centre for International Business and Management at [[Cambridge University]], a member of the board of Dean's Advisors at the [[Harvard Business School]] and a member of the academic board at [[Tel Aviv University]]."[https://www.accessindustries.com/about/academic-boards-committees/ Academic Boards and Committees: Harvard University, Cambridge University, Tel Aviv University]" ==Philanthropy== [[File:Reuven Rivlin hosting young scientists who have been awarded the Blavatnik Awards for Young Scientists, February 2018 (4568).jpg|thumb|Blavatnik and [[Israel]]i President [[Reuven Rivlin]] with young scientists who have been awarded the [[Blavatnik Awards for Young Scientists]], February 2018]] Blavatnik, the Blavatnik Family Foundation and Access companies have supported many cultural and philanthropic institutions over the past 15 years, including serving as the primary benefactors for numerous major art and cultural exhibitions, including the British Museum, Tate Modern (which named a new wing the "Blavatnik Building" in 2017{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/may/04/tate-modern-names-extension-after-oligarch-donor-len-blavatnik|title=Tate Modern names extension after billionaire Len Blavatnik|last=Ellis-Petersen|first=Hannah|date=2017-05-04|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}), Royal Opera House, National Portrait Gallery and Museum of Modern Art. Since 2007, the Blavatnik Family Foundation together with the New York Academy of Sciences has supported the [[Blavatnik Awards for Young Scientists]]. The annual award recognizes the accomplishments of outstanding young scientists in life sciences, physical sciences and engineering and provides all finalists with a significant cash prize.[http://www.nyas.org/awards/blavatnik.aspx Profile], nyas.org; accessed February 23, 2015. Blavatnik sponsors a [[Colel Chabad]] {{convert|20,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} food bank and warehouse in [[Kiryat Malakhi]], Israel, which sends monthly food shipments to 5,000 poor families in 25 Israeli cities, and before Jewish holidays to 30,000 families in 73 Israeli cities, towns and villages.[http://www.colelchabad.org/Blavatnik_Food_Banks.bp Colel Chabad profile], colelchabad.org; accessed February 23, 2015. In 2010, it was announced that Blavatnik and the Blavatnik Family Foundation would donate £75 million to the [[University of Oxford]] to establish a new school of government.[http://www.ox.ac.uk/media/news_stories/2010/100617.html Blavatnik donation of £75 million to Oxford University], ox.ac.uk; accessed February 23, 2015. The gift is one of the largest philanthropic gifts in the university's 900-year history. Blavatnik also indicated the possibility of increasing his benefaction up to £100 million over time. The [[Blavatnik School of Government]] began accepting students in September 2012, and the new permanent home of the school was constructed on the [[Radcliffe Observatory Quarter]]. The building, which was finished in summer 2015, was designed by the Swiss architects [[Herzog & de Meuron]]. The first dean of the school is professor [[Ngaire Woods]]. In 2013, [[Harvard University]] announced a $50 million donation from Blavatnik's foundation to sponsor life sciences entrepreneurship at the university[http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2013/4/29/capital-campaign-donation-innovation $50 million donation to Harvard from Blavatnik], thecrimson.com; accessed February 23, 2015. and named the first five HBS graduates to receive the Blavatnik Fellowship in Life Science Entrepreneurship{{Cite web|url=https://www.hbs.edu/news/releases/Pages/blavatnik-fellows-2013.aspx|title=Harvard Business School Names First Blavatnik Fellows in Life Science Entrepreneurship - News - Harvard Business School|website=www.hbs.edu|language=en-us|access-date=2018-05-06}}. In 2018, [[Harvard Medical School]] announced a $200 million donation from Blavatnik's foundation to sponsor research, investments in data science, and the creation of subsidized lab space for biotech startups.[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-08/harvard-med-gets-record-gift-from-blavatnik-to-speed-research Harvard Med Gets Record Gift From Blavatnik to Speed Research], bloomberg.com; accessed November 8, 2018. ==Political donations== In 2011, Blavatnik donated to both President [[Barack Obama]] and his GOP rival, former Massachusetts governor [[Mitt Romney]]."[https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/investigators-follow-flow-money-trump-wealthy-donors-russian/story?id=50100024 Special counsel probing flow of Russian-American money to Trump political funds]". ABC News. September 26, 2017. Blavatnik is a supporter of the [[Republican Party (United States)|US Republican Party]], and in 2015-2016 donated a total of $7.35 million to six Republican political candidates, including South Carolina Senator [[Lindsey Graham]], Florida Senator [[Marco Rubio]] and Arizona Senator [[John McCain]]. In February 2016, Blavatnik donated over $1 million to an anti-Donald Trump GOP group."[https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/warner-owner-len-blavatnik-pumps-1m-into-anti-donald-trump-group/ Warner owner Len Blavatnik pumps $1m into anti-Donald Trump group]". Music Business Worldwide. March 22, 2016. He also donated $1 million to the committee for the [[inauguration of Donald Trump]].{{cite web|last1=May|first1=Ruth|title=GOP campaigns took $7.35 million from oligarch linked to Russia|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/commentary/2017/08/03/tangled-web-connects-russian-oligarch-money-gop-campaigns|website=Dallas News|accessdate=28 August 2017}} In August 2017, political scientist [[Bo Rothstein]] resigned from the Blavatnik School of Government out of opposition to Blavatnik's politics.{{cite news|last1=Weaver|first1=Matthew|title=Oxford University professor resigns in Donald Trump protest|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/aug/28/oxford-university-professor-bo-rothstein-resigns-donald-trump-protest|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=The Guardian|date=28 August 2017}} Blavatnik and his American wife, Emily, also donated to [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] candidates [[Kamala Harris]], [[Chuck Schumer]], [[Andrew Cuomo]] and [[Hillary Clinton]]."[https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/07/democratic-national-convention-2016-russiasn-214123 The Russians at the DNC]". ''[[Politico]]''. July 29, 2016. In 2017, after two senior Trump administration officials went on record as being lobbyists for Blavatnik’s Access Industries{{Cite news|url=https://news.vice.com/en_ca/article/d35kgw/two-top-trump-officials-are-ex-lobbyists-for-a-billionaire-with-deep-ties-to-russian-oligarchs|title=Exclusive: Two top Trump officials are ex-lobbyists for a billionaire with deep ties to Russian oligarchs|work=VICE News|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en}}, Blavatnik was mentioned in investigations led by Special Counsel [[Robert Mueller]] into Russian donations to the administration.{{Cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/04/special-counsel-robert-mueller-is-asking-russian-oligarchs-if-they-gave-money-to-trump/|title=Special counsel Robert Mueller is asking Russian oligarchs if they gave money to Trump|work=Mother Jones|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}} Since April 2016 Blavatnik contributed $383,000 to the Republican National Committee and $1 million to Trump’s inauguration fund. However he did not give directly to the Trump campaign.{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/investigators-follow-flow-money-trump-wealthy-donors-russian/story?id=50100024|title=Special counsel probing flow of Russian-American money to Trump political funds|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2018-02-20|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}} ==Wealth== In the ''[[Sunday Times Rich List 2015]]'', Blavatnik was listed as the UK's richest person,{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-32464402 | work=BBC News | title=Music boss Len Blavatnik named as Britain's richest man | date=April 26, 2015}} with a fortune of £16.9 billion. ''[[Forbes]]'' ranks Blavatnik as the 16th richest in the world as of April 2015. ==Personal life== Blavatnik is married to Emily Appelson Blavatnik.[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/filipino-housekeeper-claims-leonard-blavatnik-won-hire-ethnicity-article-1.980530 "Filipino housekeeper claims Leonard Blavatnik won't hire her because of her ethnicity - Virginia Lim files discrimination suit in U.S."], nydailynews.com, November 21, 2011. The couple have four children. He owns a [[Listed building|grade II listed building]] in [[Kensington Palace Gardens]] which is valued at £200 million.Clementine, Katherine. [http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/west-london-news/rich-list-2015-kensington-property-9157406 " Rich List 2015: Kensington property owner Len Blavatnik top with £13.17 BILLION fortune "], ''Get West London'', 1 May 2015. Accessed 28 May 2015 Blavatnik is a friend of [[Israel]]i Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]."[https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/kremlin-linked-billionaire-netanyahu-friend-donated-to-trump-s-legal-fund-1.5453274 Kremlin-linked Billionaire, Netanyahu Friend Donated to Trump's Private Legal Fund]". ''[[Haaretz]]''. September 25, 2017. Blavatnik is also a longtime friend and business partner of Ukrainian-born Russian oligarch Viktor Vekselberg, one of Russia's richest men, who is close to Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]]. Leonid was rumoured a "rival" investor to [[Sheldon Adelson]] in Israeli newspaper wars, according to Caleb Ben-David of Israeli JPOST. ==Honours== Blavatnik was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] in the [[2017 Birthday Honours]] for services to philanthropy.{{London Gazette|issue=61962|supp=y|page=B2|date=17 June 2017}} ==See also== *[[Kensington Palace {{Spanish name|Sanz|Mancebo}} '''Lorenzo Sanz Mancebo''' (born 9 August 1943 in [[Madrid]]) is a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[businessman]], former president of [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid Club de Fútbol]] and former owner of [[Málaga CF|Málaga Club de Fútbol]], where his son [[Fernando Sanz|Fernando]] (a former player with Real Madrid and Málaga) served as the club's president.
== Early life == In his youth, Sanz played as a goalkeeper for several minor league Madrilenian teams, including [[Puerta Bonita]]. An astute businessman, he made his fortune in real estate and construction.
== Real Madrid President == Sanz was director of Real Madrid from 1985 to 1995. He became chairman of Real Madrid on 26 November 1995 after [[Ramón Mendoza]] was forced to resign due to the economic, social, and sporting problems of the club. Sanz tried to turn the club around by bringing in star players like [[Davor Šuker]] and [[Predrag Mijatović]] with his own money. This led to a long-awaited [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] victory, which Real Madrid had not won since 1966, as the club clinched both the 1998 and 2000 tournaments, now named the UEFA Champions League.
However, the two UEFA Champions League triumphs were not enough to hide the financial problems that still plagued the club and in elections a few weeks after the 2000 final, he lost the presidency to [[Florentino Pérez]].
== Negotiations with Parma == Between June 2005 and January 2006, Sanz was negotiating with [[Parma F.C.|Parma Football Club]] in ''Amministrazione Straordinaria'' to become the club's new owner. Guido Angiolini and Enrico Bondi, the two officers appointed by the Italian government to restore Parma, and its main sponsor [[Parmalat]], were the two persons involved in the operations with Sanz. The first time Parma announced negotiations with Sanz was in August 2005. Both President Guido Angiolini and government-appointed administrator Enrico Bondi asked for €27.5 million, but the negotiations were not as smooth as some predicted.
Until January 2006, the Sanz family was still transacting business with Bondi and Angiolini, but to no avail. In an interview with ''[[Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' in January 2006, President Angiolini stated that, "If, by the 16th, the deal with the Sanz family has not been closed, we will set about finding a new buyer." Sanz has seemed the most likely buyer of the club since last August when he made an initial payment of €7.5 million ($9.07 million) on the full price of €27.5 million. However, he has not yet paid the outstanding €20 million. Parma administrators stated that after 16 January 2006, the club is free to find other interested buyers as the contract with Sanz expired on 15 January 2006. Other interested buyers include the owner of Spain's Alamak Espana Trade, [[Russian oligarch]] Abram Reznikov. The uncertainty over the club's future has become a source of increasing frustration for Parma supporters. The deal with Sanz was a big dilemma for Parma supporters. In some papers, this deal was referred to as "The never ending story." Parma supporters were longing for a positive ending. Sanz visited Parma a couple of times, and he even turned up at the [[Stadio Ennio Tardini]] to follow some of Parma's matches in [[Serie A]]. Because of his withdrawal from the deal and failure to pay the rest of the sum of €20.5 million, Lorenzo Sanz Senior and Lorenzo Sanz Junior lost much of their credibility.
== Later years == Sanz has recently announced that he will put himself up for election once again for the vacant President's position at Real Madrid, losing it to [[Ramón Calderón]].
On July 2006, Sanz purchased [[Málaga CF|Málaga Club de Fútbol]]. He sold the club in 2010 to a [[Qatar]]i investor.
In May 2008, it has been reported that he is looking to buy Italian club [[A.S. Bari|Associazione Sportiva Bari]],<ref>[http://www.tuttomercatoweb.com/index.php?action=read&id=102108 TUTTO MERCATO WEB - Bari, Sanz interessato all'acquisto<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and that the Bari owners have given him 10 days to close the deal, which is rumored to be around €15 million.<ref>[http://www.tuttomercatoweb.com/index.php?action=read&id=105398 TUTTO MERCATO WEB - Bari, ultimatum a Sanz<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
On September 2008, he was briefly jailed charged of fraud by a bank after trying to get paid a fake cheque. The complaint was withdrawn on December 2008.
On 11 November 2009, it was reported by Spanish newspaper ''El Pais'' that Sanz was arrested trying to smuggle [[work of art|artwork]] out of Spain.
== Family == Sanz is the father-in-law of former Real Madrid and Spanish defender [[Míchel Salgado]], who married his daughter Malula.
