{{Other people||Phil Adams (disambiguation){{!}}Phil Adams}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Phillip Adams | post-nominals = {{Post-nominals|size=100|country=AUS|AO|FAHA}} {{Post-nominals|size=100|country=UK|FRSA}} | image = Phillip Adams.jpg | alt = | caption = Adams speaking at the
2010 Global Atheist Convention | birth_name = Phillip Andrew Hedley Adams | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1939|07|12}} | birth_place = [[Maryborough, Victoria|Maryborough]], Victoria | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | other_names = | known_for = Revival of Australian cinema;
Public intellectualism | occupation = Film producer; journalist; broadcaster; former advertising executive | spouse = Rosemary Fawcett (dis.)
[[Patrice Newell]] | residence = [[Hunter Region|Hunter Valley]], [[New South Wales]] | religion = }} '''Phillip Andrew Hedley Adams''' [[Order of Australia|AO]] [[Australian Academy of the Humanities|FAHA]] [[Royal Society of Arts|FRSA]] (born 12 July 1939) is an Australian [[Humanism|humanist]], social commentator, broadcaster, public intellectual and farmer. He hosts ''[[Late Night Live]]'', an [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) program on [[ABC Radio National|Radio National]] four nights a week. He also writes a weekly column for ''[[The Weekend Australian]]''. Adams has had careers in advertising and film production and has served on many non-profit boards including [[Greenpeace Australia]], [[Ausflag]], [[Care Australia]], [[Film Victoria]], [[National Museum of Australia]], both the [[Adelaide Festival of Ideas|Adelaide]] and [[Ideas Festival|Brisbane]] festivals of ideas, the Montsalvat Arts Society and the [[Don Dunstan#Legacy|Don Dunstan Foundation]]. Adams has been appointed both a member and subsequently an officer of the [[Order of Australia]]; and he has received numerous awards including five honorary doctorates from Australian universities; Republican of the Year 2005; the Senior ANZAC Fellowship; the Australian Humanist of the Year, the [[Golden Lion]] at Cannes; the Longford Award; a [[Walkley Award]]; and the Henry Lawson Australian Arts Award. In 1997 the [[International Astronomical Union]] named a minor planet orbiting the sun between Mars and Jupiter after him. A [[National Trust of Australia|National Trust]] poll elected him one of Australia's 100 [[Australian Living Treasures|national living treasures]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.au/nsw/NationalLivingTreasures|title=National Living Treasures|publisher=[[National Trust of Australia]]|date=2012|accessdate=23 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129093613/http://www.nationaltrust.org.au/nsw/NationalLivingTreasures|archivedate=29 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Early years== Adams was born in [[Maryborough, Victoria|Maryborough]], Victoria, the only child of [[Congregational Church]] minister, the Reverend Charles Adams. His childhood was anything but idyllic and his parents separated when he was young. Interviewed in 2006, Adams said that:{{cite interview|last=Adams|first=Phillip|interviewer=[[Richard Fidler]]|title=Broadcaster Phillip Adams in conversation with Richard Fidler|type=Radio interview|url=http://www.abc.net.au/queensland/conversations/stories/s1690728.htm|format=transcript and streaming audio|work=The Backyard|publisher=[[ABC Radio National]]|location=Australia|date=19 July 2006|page= |pages= |access-date=23 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101095832/http://www.abc.net.au/queensland/conversations/stories/s1690728.htm|archive-date=2007-11-01|dead-url=yes|quote=}}
My first memories were my mother... absolutely dependent on the begging bowl – that little round dish with a piece of cloth at the bottom where parishioners would put a couple of bob. When dad went off to the war, I was taken up by my grandparents... and lived on a dirt-poor farm... I lived in penury for the first 10, 15 years of my life. ... Mother dumped [my father] in favour of a rather sleazy businessman ... a sociopath who tried to murder me ... I spent my latter part of my childhood trying to protect my mother from this psycho.
Of his education he has said: "I was forced to leave school before completing my secondary education and the only job I could get was working in advertising." Adams joined the [[Australian Communist Party]]{{cite interview|last=Adams|first=Phillip|interviewer=[[Richard Fidler]]|title=Phillip Adams|type=Radio interview|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2006/09/14/1740844.htm|format=transcript and streaming audio|work=Conversations with Richard Fidler|publisher=[[ABC Local Radio]]|location=Australia|date=14 September 2006|page= |pages= |access-date=23 December 2014|quote=}} at age 16, whilst employed in advertising, but left at age 19. He has often compared dogmatic belief in communism to dogmatic belief in [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} ==Career== Adams began his advertising career with [[Foote Cone & Belding]] and, later, with Brian Monahan and Lyle Dayman, became a partner in the agency Monahan Dayman Adams. They took that company to a successful public listing and Adams became a millionaire in the process.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He developed successful campaigns such as ''[[Life. Be in it.]]'',{{cite web|title=Animation cel of 'Norm' from the 'Life. Be in it' campaign, 1993 – 1994|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=12209&search=alexander&images=&c=1&s=|work=Powerhouse Museum Collection Search 2.53|format=Acetate, paper, cardboard|author1=Stitt, Alexander|author2=Adams, Phillip|location=South Yarra, Victoria, Australia|date=1993–1994|publisher=[[Powerhouse Museum]], Sydney}} ''[[Slip-Slop-Slap|Slip, Slop, Slap]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sunsmart.com.au/browse.asp?ContainerID=1808|title=Page Not Found|first=SunSmart|last=Victoria|website=SunSmart}} ''Break down the Barriers'', ''Guess whose mum's got a Whirlpool'' and ''Watch the big men fly for a Herbert Adams Pie'', working with talent such as [[Fred Schepisi]], Alex Stitt, [[Peter Best (composer)|Peter Best]], [[Robyn Archer]] and Mimmo Cozzolino. Adams left the advertising industry in the 1980s. Monahan Dayman Adams purchased the successful Sydney agency [[Mojo (advertising)|MoJo]] in 1987 and carried on as MojoMDA. Its lineage can today be traced to Publicis Mojo, an Australian subsidiary of the French [[multinational corporation|multinational]] advertising and communications company holding [[Publicis Groupe]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He wrote regular columns for ''[[The Age]]'' and ''[[The Bulletin]]''. He currently writes a weekly column for ''The Australian''. ===Film work=== Adams played a key role in the revival of the [[Cinema of Australia|Australian film industry]] during the 1970s.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/03/06/1046826480126.html?oneclick=true|location=Melbourne|work=[[The Age]]|date=7 March 2003|accessdate=23 December 2014|title=Bazza turns 30}} He was the author of a 1969 report{{cite web|url=http://www.tabula-rasa.info/AusHorror/OzHorrorFilms4.html|title=A Brief History of the Film Industry in Australia and New Zealand|work=Killer Koalas: Australian (and New Zealand) Horror Films|format=Appendix|author=Hood, Robert|date=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} which led to legislation by Prime Minister [[John Gorton]] in 1970 for an Australian Film and Television Development Corporation (later the [[Australian Film Commission]]) and the Experimental Film Fund. Together with [[Barry Jones (Australian politician)|Barry Jones]], Adams was a motivating force behind the [[Australian Film Television and Radio School]] which was established under the [[Whitlam|Whitlam government]].{{cite web|url=http://screenforever.org.au/program/phillip-adams-ao/|title=Phillip Adams AO|work=Screen Forever|publisher=Screen Producers Australia|date=November 2014|accessdate=23 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223132555/http://screenforever.org.au/program/phillip-adams-ao/|archivedate=23 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} Adams played a key role in the development of the [[South Australian Film Corporation]], which was created in 1972 and became a model for similar bodies in other Australian states; and in the establishment of the [[Australia Council]] and the [[Australian Film Development Corporation]], later known as the Australian Film Commission, the [[Film Finance Corporation Australia]], and [[Screen Australia]]. As head of delegation to the [[Cannes Film Festival]], Adams signed Australia's first co-production agreements with France and the UK. He was Chairman of the [[Australian Film Institute]], the Film and Television Board of the Australia Council, the Australian Film Commission, and Film Australia. He helped establish the Australian Caption Service, which provides services for hearing-impaired television viewers – and the Travelling Film Festival to take quality films into rural areas.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} In the 1960s Adams co-wrote, co-produced and co-directed (as well as serving as cinematographer for) his first feature film ''[[Jack and Jill: A Postscript]]'' (1969); the first feature to win the [[Australian Film Institute Award|AFI Award]],{{cite web|url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/23/carlton-australian-revival.html|author=Hodson, Bruce|title=The Carlton Ripple and the Australian Film Revival|work=Screening the Past|date=|accessdate=15 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218063047/http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/23/carlton-australian-revival.html|archivedate=18 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} and the first Australian film to win the Grand Prix at an international festival. Adams produced or co-produced other features including the critically panned but hugely popular film adaptation of Barry Humphries' ''[[The Adventures of Barry McKenzie]]'', directed by [[Bruce Beresford]], which became the most successful Australian film ever made up to that time. Other films include ''[[The Naked Bunyip]]'', ''[[Don's Party]]'', ''[[The Getting of Wisdom (film)|The Getting of Wisdom]]'', ''Lonely Hearts'', ''[[We of the Never Never]]'', ''[[Grendel Grendel Grendel]]'', ''Fighting Back'', ''Hearts and Minds'' and ''[[Abra Cadabra (1983 film)|Abra Cadabra]]''. ===Broadcasting=== Adams initially presented a late-night program on Sydney commercial radio station [[2UE]] during the late 1980s and early 1990s before succeeding [[Virginia Bell]] in 1991 at ABC Radio National's ''Late Night Live'', a magazine{{endash}}style program that broadcasts analysis of current events to Australian and international politics, science, philosophy and culture. ''Late Night Live'' is broadcast across Australia on ABC Radio National, as well as on [[Radio Australia]] and the Internet. The program is broadcast live from 22:00 [[Australian Time|AEST]]/[[Australian Daylight Saving Time|ADST]] and is repeated the following day at 16:00 AEST/ADST.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/latenightlive/|work=ABC Radio National|title=About us: Late Night Live|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} A serious discussion of world issues, the program is tempered with Adams' gentle and ironic humour.{{cite book|author=Luker, Philip|title=Phillip Adams: The Ideas Man – A Life Revealed|page=206|date=20 April 2011|publisher=JoJo Publishing|isbn=978-0-9870734-6-4}} Regular contributors include [[Bruce Shapiro]] and [[Beatrix Campbell]]. At times, Adams refers [[tongue-in-cheek]] to his listeners as "the listener" or "Gladys", as though he had only one listener; he also refers to listeners collectively as "Gladdies". In more recent years, Adams has begun introducing the show saying "Good evening Gladdies and Poddies", in reference to the show's growing [[podcast]] listener base. The current theme music is a short extract from [[Elena Kats-Chernin]]'s ''[[Wild Swans (ballet)|Wild Swans Concert Suite]]'', performed by the [[Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra]] with [[soprano]] [[Jane Sheldon]], chosen in 2010. From 2007 to 2010, the theme music was Kats-Chernin's "Russian Rag", which Adams humorously refers to as "The Waltz of the Wombat". The previous music was [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s [[Keyboard concertos by Johann Sebastian Bach#Concerto in C minor, BWV 1060|Concerto for oboe, violin and orchestra in C minor, BWV 1060]]: III. ''Allegro''. ===Other work=== Adams was the foundation chairman of the Commission for the Future, established by the [[Hawke government]] to build bridges between science and the community. In 1988 the Commission won a major United Nations award for educating Australia on the issue of greenhouse and [[climate change]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He chaired the [[National Australia Day Council]]; whose principal task was to choose the Australian of the Year. He also chaired the Advisory Board for the Centre of the Mind at the [[University of Sydney]] and the [[Australia National University]] and has been a board member of Greenpeace Australia, CARE Australia, the National Museum of Australia, The Australian Centre for Social Innovation, the [[Adelaide Festival of Ideas]] and Brisbane's [[Ideas Festival]]. He was co-founder of the [[Australian Skeptics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.celebrityspeakers.com.au/media-speakers/phillip-adams/|title=Phillip Adams AO|work=Speaker Profile|publisher=The Celebrity Speakers Bureau|date=2014|accessdate=23 December 2014}} Adams is the author or editor of more than 20 books, including ''The Unspeakable Adams'', ''Adams Versus God'', ''The Penguin Book of Australian Jokes'', ''Retreat from Tolerance'', ''Talkback and A Billion Voices'', ''Adams Ark'', and, with Lee Burton, ''Emperors of the Air''. [[Robert Manne]] has described Adams as "the emblematic figurehead of the pro-[[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] left [[intelligentsia]]".{{cite news|author=Manne, Robert|authorlink=Robert Manne |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/robert-manne/labor-must-confront-its-identity-crisis/2004/10/17/1097951554223.html|location=Melbourne|work=[[The Age]]|title=Labor must confront its identity crisis|date=18 October 2004|accessdate=23 December 2014}} Adams had a close relationship with every Labor leader from Gough Whitlam to [[Kevin Rudd]], advising on public relations, advertising and policy issues. However, on 19 July 2006, he was reported as saying of the Labor Party:
They hate me. I think Kim Beazley is a serious error. I think the party's been going downhill federally ever since Keating left ... The Labor Party's hardly worth feeding federally.
In 2010, Adams resigned from the Labor Party after Rudd was defeated as the [[Leader of the Australian Labor Party|Leader of the Labor Party]] at the [[Australian Labor Party leadership election, 2010|2010 Labor leadership spill]].{{cite news|title=Why I quit the Labor Party|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/why-i-quit-the-labor-party/story-e6frg8h6-1225886243738|author=Adams, Phillip|work=[[The Australian]]|date=|accessdate= }} In 1995 Adams argued against [[Section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975]], saying that a better response to expressions of racial hatred was "public debate, not legal censure".{{Cite book|title=The Role of the Media|last=Adams|first=Phillip|publisher=|year=1995|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} Adams' life and extracurricular activities have made him a source of interest to fans and foes of all persuasions for many years. Australia's [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation|security intelligence organisation]] kept an extensive [[ASIO File]] on Adams. The file began at about the time he turned 16 years of age.{{cite news|work=[[The Australian|The Weekend Australian Magazine]]|author=Adams, Phillip|date=16 July 2005|title=Adams file|accessdate=}} ==Personal life== [[File:(1) Stoneleigh (Darley Street)-1.jpg|right|thumb|"Stoneleigh", Adams's former home]] Adams is married to [[Patrice Newell]]. He has four daughters: three with his first wife, Rosemary Fawcett, and one with Newell. He lives on "Elmswood", a large property near [[Gundy]] in the [[Hunter Region]] in mid-northern New South Wales. He and his wife grow garlic, olives and farm organically fed cattle. He has a home in [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]], an inner suburb of Sydney. Prior to this, Adams lived for some time in "Stoneleigh", a heritage-listed house{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDetails.aspx?ID=2420152|title=House "Stoneleigh" Including Interior, Front Fence and Grounds – NSW Environment & Heritage|website=www.environment.nsw.gov.au}} in [[Darlinghurst, New South Wales|Darlinghurst]]. Adams is a collector of rare antiques, including Egyptian, Roman and Greek sculptures and [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifact]]s. He has written "I'd been an atheist since I was five."{{cite web|url=http://jmm.aaa.net.au/articles/4678.htm|title=I Am Proud That|author1=Adams, Phillip|author2=Croucher, Rowland|publisher=John Mark Ministries|date=October 1998|archive-url=http://www.melbournesynagogue.org.au/news/haatid/q4_1998/q4_98_02.html|archive-date=5 January 2003|accessdate=23 December 2014}} In 1979 a portrait of Adams by artist [[Wes Walters]] won the [[Archibald Prize]]. ==Honours and awards== *Windgrove Laureate (2004) *Senior [[ANZAC Fellow]] (1981) *[[Henry Lawson]] Arts Award (1987) *[[United Nations Media Award]] (2005) *Multiple AFI Awards for various films *Honorary Doctor of the University, [[Griffith University]] *Honorary Doctor of Letters, [[Edith Cowan University]] (2003){{cite web|title=ECU Honorary Award Recipients|work=[[Edith Cowan University]]|url=https://www.ecu.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/378654/ECU_Honorary_Award_Recipients.pdf}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Honorary Doctor of Letters, [[University of Sydney]] (2005){{cite web|title=Robyn Archer and Phillip Adams honoured|date=4 May 2005|work=[[The University honorary doctorate from Macquarie University|date=17 April 2014|publisher=[[Macquarie University]]|url=http://mq.edu.au/newsroom/2014/04/17/phillip-adams-ao-receives-honorary-doctorate-from-macquarie-university/}} *[[Officer of the Order of Australia]] (AO) 1992, for service to the A '''qualified institutional buyer''' ('''QIB'''), in United States law and finance, is a purchaser of [[securities]] that is deemed financially sophisticated and is legally recognized by securities market regulators to need less protection from issuers than most public investors. Typically, the qualifications for this designation are based on an investor's total [[assets under management]] and specific legal conditions in the country where the fund is located. [[Rule 144A]] requires an institution to manage at least $100 million in securities from issuers not affiliated with the institution to be considered a QIB. If the institution is a bank or savings and loans thrift they must have a net worth of at least $25 million. If the institution is a registered dealer acting for its own account it must in the aggregate own and invest on a discretionary basis at least $10 million of securities of issuers not affiliated with the dealer.
Certain [[private placements]] of [[stock|stocks]] and [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] are made available only to qualified institutional buyers to limit regulatory restrictions and public filing requirements.
== Requirements == The [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) requires that an entity meet one of the following requirements to qualify as a QIB: * Any of the following entities, acting for its own account or the accounts of other QIBs, that in the aggregate owns and invests on a discretionary basis at least $100 million in securities of issuers that are not affiliated with the entity: :* An insurance company :* An investment company registered under the [[Investment Company Act of 1940]] :* A Small Business Investment Company licensed by the US Small Business Administration under the [[Small Business Investment Act of 1958]] :* A plan established and maintained by a state, its political subdivisions, or state agency, for the benefit of its employees :* An employee benefit plan falling under the [[Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974]] :* A trust fund whose trustee is a bank or trust company and whose participants are exclusively plans established for the benefit of state employees or employee benefit plans, except trust funds that include as participants individual retirement accounts or H.R. 10 plans :* A business development company as defined in section 202(a)(22) of the [[Investment Advisers Act of 1940]]. :* A 501(c)(3) charitable organization, corporation (other than a bank or a savings and loan association), partnership, or Massachusetts or similar business trust; and :* An investment adviser registered under the [[Investment Advisers Act of 1940]]. * Any registered dealer, acting for its own account or the accounts of other QIBs, that in the aggregate owns and invests on a discretionary basis at least $10 million of securities of issuers that are not affiliated with the dealer. * Any registered dealer acting in a [[riskless principal]] transaction on behalf of a ''qualified institutional buyer''. * Any investment company registered under the Investment Company Act, acting for its own account or for the accounts of other QIBs, that is part of a family of investment companies which own in the aggregate at least $100 million in securities of issuers, other than issuers that are affiliated with the investment company or are part of such family of investment companies. * Any entity, all of the equity owners of which are QIBs, acting for its own account or the accounts of other QIBs. * Any bank or any savings and loan association or other institution, acting for its own account or the accounts of other QIBs, that in the aggregate owns and invests on a discretionary basis at least $100 million in securities of issuers that are not affiliated with it and that has an audited net worth of at least $25 million as demonstrated in its latest annual financial statements, as of a date not more than 16 months preceding the date of sale under [[Rule 144A]] in the case of a US bank or savings and loan association, and not more than 18 months preceding the date of sale for a foreign bank or savings and loan association or equivalent institution.<ref>[http://us.practicallaw.com/1-382-3730 PLC - Qualified Institutional Buyer (QIB)]</ref>
==See also== *[[Accredited investor]] *[[Private placement]] *[[Rule 144A]] *[[Regulation D (SEC)|Reg D]] *[[Investment Company Act of 1940]] *[[Securities Act of 1933]] *[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]

{{Infobox person | name = Richard Blaize | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 1845 | birth_place = [[Freetown]] | death_date = 1904 | death_place = [[Lagos]], Caxton, Marina | education = | occupation = [[Businessman]] | spouse = | parents = | children = Mrs Obasa }}
'''Richard Beale Blaize''' (November 22, 1845 – September 21, 1904) was a [[West African]] businessman, newspaper publisher, financier, and black nationalist of [[Sierra Leonean]] and [[Nigerian]] heritage.
==Early life== Richard Olamilege Blaize was born in [[Freetown]], Sierra Leone, to the family of [[emancipated]] [[slaves]] of Yoruba origin. His parents were Ojelabi Olapajuokun (who later took the name John Blaize) and Maria Blaize.<ref name="Adeniran">{{cite book|last1=Adeniran|first1=Adedapo|title=Nigeria The Case for Peaceful and Friendly Dissolution|publisher=Arymson Publicity|page=44|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5hDJvxt_O-MC&pg=PT3&dq=richard+Beale+Blaize+olamilege&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q=olamilege&f=false|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Tarikh|title=R.B. Blaize: Merchant Prince of West Africa|publisher=Longman, 1966|page=71}}</ref> At an early age, he attended a mission school and was nurtured in the Christian way. He started work as an [[apprentice]] for a printer in Freetown but soon left the country for the [[Lagos Colony]] in 1862.
==Career in business and political activism==
===Business=== After arriving Lagos in 1862, Blaize worked as a printer for Robert Campbell, editor of Anglo-American.<ref name="Teniola">{{cite web|last1=Teniola|first1=Eric|title=Sierra Leon: The Creoles in Nigeria|url=http://www.thisissierraleone.com/sierra-leone-the-creoles-in-nigeria/|website=This Is Sierra Leone|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref> He then left printing for [[merchandise]] trading and importation. In trading, the participants were numerous, especially those from Lagos; most of the traders mainly dealt with exchanging goods with exporters and a few delved into [[exportation]].<ref name="Olukoju">Ayodeji Olukoju. "Anatomy of Business-Government Relations: Fiscal Policy and Mercantile Pressure Group Activity in Nigeria, 1916-1933", ''African Studies Review'', Vol. 38, No. 1, April 1995, p. 24.</ref> A number of traders owned steamers, which were used to navigate the [[Niger River]] to buy goods from groups across river, and some even boasted they showed the imperialists how to move across the river. Blaize was among a few of the Lagos merchants to be very successful in trading; he was an importer and was also involved with trade across the Niger. Though the ruinous approach of competitors led to many indigenous enterprises foundling not the least helped with the dominance of [[sole proprietorships]], Blaize thrived in the midst of strong competition and became one of the wealthiest West Africans of his time.<ref name="Lipschitz">Mark R. Lipschutz, R. Kent Rasmussen. ''Dictionary of African Historical Biography'', Aldine Pub. Co., 1978, p. 32. {{ISBN|0-520-05179-3}}.</ref> He was included in the European Lagos Chamber of Commerce constituted in 1888 and was on the 1898 Commission on Trade in Lagos.<ref name="JHK" />
===Political activism=== He was a prominent member of the [[Royal African Society]] during the second half of the nineteenth century. He was also at various times, a [[newspaper publisher]]. He entered the [[newsprint]] business in 1880, with the launch of ''[[The Lagos Times and Gold Coast Colony Advertiser]]''.<ref name="JHK" /> The paper brought on Mr [[Mojola Agbebi]], who later became prominent and known for his views on [[cultural]] [[Nationalism]].<ref name="Obichere">Boniface I. Obichere. ''Studies in Southern Nigerian History'', Routledge, 1982, p. 106, {{ISBN|0-7146-3106-X}}.</ref> However, the life of the newspaper was short, it folded in 1884. He was thereafter approached by [[John Payne Jackson]], a [[Liberia]]n emigrant who wanted to re-invent the Times. After much prodding, Blaize agreed to publish a new rag: the ''Lagos Weekly Times''. Through his newspapers, he took an active part in demanding more education, better representation for Africans in Lagos, self-government, and pushed for a separation of Lagos Colony from the Gold Coast Colony.
Blaize's political clout in [[Lagos Colony]] was demonstrated in 1901 during the contest for the [[Oba of Lagos|Lagos Throne]]. After Governor [[William MacGregor]] refused to accept any of the rival candidates (Oduntan and Ajose Dawudu) for the Obaship, one of the king-makers (Yesufu Omo-Oba) introduced [[Eshugbayi Eleko]] to Blaize, and Blaize in turn introduced Eshugbayi Eleko to Governor MacGregor, who recognized Eleko as Oba of Lagos.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Patrick|title=Modern and Traditional Elites in the Politics of Lagos|publisher=Cambridge University Press, Apr 17, 1975|isbn=9780521204392|page=163}}</ref>
==Private life== Blaize married Emily Cole in 1871 and the couple had 6 children<ref name="Mann">{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Kristin|title=Marrying Well: Marriage, Status and Social Change among the Educated Elite in Colonial Lagos|publisher=Cambridge University Press, Dec 5, 1985|isbn=9780521307017|page=83}}</ref> including Charlotte Olajumoke, who in 1902, married Dr [[Orisadipe Obasa]]. Emily Cole died in 1895.<ref name="Mann" />
==Death, legacy and philanthropy== In the 1890s Blaize's financial worth was estimated to be about £150,000.<ref name="Forrest">{{cite book|last1=Forrest|first1=Tom|title=The Advance of African Capital: The Growth of Nigerian Private Enterprise|publisher=University of Virginia Press, 1994|isbn=9780813915623|page=14|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xfHsJMBLWlsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Blaize+advance+of+african+capital&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4_43zxYPRAhWJ3YMKHcdQBWoQ6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=blaize&f=false|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref> Blaize donated £500 in memory of [[Mary Kingsley]] to the [[Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine]].<ref name="JHK">{{cite book|last1=Kopytoff|first1=Jean Herskovits|title=A preface to modern Nigeria: the "Sierra Leonians" in Yoruba, 1830-1890|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press, 1965|pages=283–284|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref> When he died in 1904, he bequeathed £3,000 for the foundation of the Blaize Memorial Institute in Abeokuta, which opened in 1909<ref name="Forrest" /> and functioned well into the 1970s.<ref name="Cole">{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Patrick|title=Modern and Traditional Elites in the Politics of Lagos|publisher=Cambridge University Press, 1975|isbn=9780521204392|page=213 n11}}</ref> Blaize kept his connection with Freetown, his place of birth, bequeathing £500 to the Princess Christian Hospital there.<ref name="JHK" /> Blaize left an estate valued at £60,000 to his children.<ref name="Mann" />
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}}

{{Infobox company |name = Rideau Recognition |logo = Rideau Logo.jpg |logo_size = 230px |type = [[Private company|Private]] |founded = 1912 |location_city = [[Montreal]] and [[New York City|New York]] |location_country= |industry = [[Human resources]] [[outsourcing]] |services = Corporate recognition solutions |homepage = [http://www.rideau.com/ www.Rideau.com] }}
'''Rideau''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|iː|d|oʊ}} {{respell|REE|doh}}; {{IPA-fr|ʁido}}) Recognition is a private, North American based company that provides corporate and governmental recognition programs and products. Founded in 1912 as the Stephenson Company, the company has undergone several buyouts and ventures in different geographical markets. Rideau was the first [[Canada|Canadian]] company to produce the [[Order of Canada]], the country's highest civilian [[order (decoration)|decoration]], as well as the first Canadian company to be granted its own [[Coat of Arms]] by [[Canadian Heraldic Authority|The Heraldic Authority]].
==History== [[Image:Rideau Hall04.jpg|thumb|left|[[Rideau Hall]], the company's [[namesake]]]]
===Growth and Transition=== In 1912 the Stephenson Company, situated on Saint-Maurice Street in [[old Montreal]], began as a producer of emblematic jewelry for associations such as the [[Freemasonry|Masons]], the [[Knights of Columbus]], and other organizations. During [[World War I|World Wars I]] and [[World War II|II]], the company produced military insignia for the armed forces.<ref name="Rideau">{{cite web |url=http://www.rideau.com/en/about_history.asp |title=Rideau History |accessdate=2009-01-16 |publisher= Rideau}}</ref> However, in the mid 50’s the company's shares were sold to a U.S.-based company that moved Stephenson Company's headquarters to [[Montreal north|Montreal North]]. The company was later sold back to two Montrealers who had numerous business interests but nevertheless, Stephenson went into a steady state of decline.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}}
By 1968, The Stephenson Company was almost bankrupt and was reduced to a staff of five. In that same year, Stephenson was purchased by Ed and Phyllis Hart.<ref name="Rideau"/> Its largest customer was [[Avon Products, Inc.|Avon Cosmetics]], which used the company's awards to help incentivize its sales force.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} In the 1970s Avon began selling Stephenson's jewelry door-to-door along with its traditional [[cosmetics]], which proved successful and helped both Avon and Stephenson flourish.<ref name="Fix">{{cite web |url=http://list.canadianbusiness.com/rankings/profit100/2008/success-stories/article.aspx?id=20080601_198708_198708 |title=Mr. Fix It |accessdate=2009-02-26 |publisher= Canadian Business Online}}</ref> In 1974, the Harts partnered with Maurice Bradden of D’Orlan Jeweler’s, helping to launch its manufacturing capabilities on the European continent in the [[Republic of Ireland]]. The facility produced [[Nina Ricci (brand)|Nina Ricci]] fashion jewelry in the European Common Market.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} In 1978, the Harts sold the operation to their four children and family friend<ref name="Rideau"/> and continued to expand in Europe. In 1979, The Stephenson company opened a subsidiary, The Jeweller's Guild, in the United Kingdom.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} The Jeweler's Guild sold fashion jewelry exclusively by mail order.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} In 1980 other subsidiaries were set up in France, Holland and Germany and they too sold fashion jewelry by mail order.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} Stephenson and its subsidiary companies did well until [[Modern economic history of UK#1979–1990: the Thatcher era|1982]], when the company's over-expansion coupled with the economic recession forced the company to change and reinvent itself.<ref name="Fix"/> [[File:OrderofCanadaFemale.jpg|thumb|right|Rideau was the first [[Canadian]] company to produce the [[Order of Canada]], the country's highest civilian [[order (decoration)|decoration]].]] In 1983, the newly restructured Stephenson Company started producing the [[Order of Canada]], the country's highest civilian [[order (decoration)|decoration]].<ref name="Rideau"/> Up until The Stephenson company was granted permission to produce the award, it had been produced solely in [[England]] by [[Crown Jewels of the United Kingdom|crown jeweler]] [[Garrard & Co|Garrards of London]].<ref>McCreery, Christopher (2006). ''The Order of Canada'', p.196. [[University of Toronto Press]], Toronto. {{ISBN|0-8020-3940-5}}.</ref>
At the suggestion of [[Bruce W. Beatty|Bruce Beatty]], the chief designer of the [[Canadian Honours System]], the owners renamed the company ''Rideau'' to reflect their service the [[Governor General of Canada]], who resides in [[Rideau Hall]] in [[Ottawa]].<ref>McCreery, Christopher (2006). ''The Order of Canada'', p.336. [[University of Toronto Press]], Toronto. {{ISBN|0-8020-3940-5}}.</ref>
In 1989, Rideau shifted its focus from government decorations and medals to their current focus of corporate recognition and point-based recognition solutions. In 2006, Rideau acquired Recognition Management Institute (RMI) a company whose focus was helping businesses grow by building relationships with their employees and customers. Rideau made an investment in analytic data (big data) research in 2008 and proved the link between employee recognition and company's Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). In that same year, RMI became "Vistance Learning". By 2012, the implementation of Vistance Analytics made Rideau the first data-driven recognition company. In 2015, Vistance was fully deployed within a major global financial services company.<ref>http://www.rideau.comj</ref>
===Business under the Rideau name=== Towards the end of the 80’s promotional products and fashion jewelry were increasingly being off-shored to the Far East, so the company began focusing on corporate recognition programs. It began providing fully outsourced recognition programs to [[Royal Bank of Canada|RBC]], [[Scotiabank]], [[Bank of Montreal|BMO]], [[Molson]], [[Alcan]], [[Canadian Pacific]], and the [[Government of Canada]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://list.canadianbusiness.com/rankings/profit100/2008/success-stories/article.aspx?id=20080601_198708_198708 |title= Canada's Fastest Growing Companies |accessdate=2009-01-16 |format= |publisher= ''[[Canadian Business]]''}}</ref> In 1991, Rideau Recognition became the first Canadian company to be granted its own [[Coat of Arms]] by [[Canadian Heraldic Authority|The Heraldic Authority]], bearing the [[Latin]] motto ''Opus excellentiae'' ("Impressions of excellence").<ref name="Rideau"/>
Rideau Recognition is also a sponsor of [[Recognition Professionals International]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.recognition.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=147 |title=Sponsorship |accessdate=2009-01-23 |publisher=[[Recognition Professionals International]]}}</ref>
===Acquisitions and Alliances=== In April 2006, Rideau Recognition announced their acquisition of Recognition Management Institute (RMI), a London, Ontario-based consulting organization specializing in training managers how to recognize and retain top employers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com|title=Online Press Release Distribution Service - PRWeb|website=PRWeb}}</ref>
In August 2015, Rideau Recognition executed a definitive asset purchase agreement with Birks Group, Inc. whereby Birks Group sold its corporate sales division, also known as "Birks Business" to Rideau for CAD $5.625 million (approximately USD $4.3 million.<ref>newswire.ca "Birks Group and Rideau announce strategic alliance: Rideau acquires Birks Corporate Sales Division and the two enter into supply and licensing agreements for Birks Business products"</ref>
On August 1, 2017, Rideau acquired Pressed Metal Products, a Vancouver-based company that manufactures emblematic insignia jewelry, awards and medals.<ref name="rideau.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.rideau.com|title=Rideau Recognition Solutions|website=Rideau Recognition Solutions}}</ref>
===Rebranding=== In March 2017, Rideau Recognition underwent a rebranding which included a new logo, website, corporate signature and colors and a new Vistance platform and proprietary score called Recognition Quotient (RQ).<ref>newswire.ca "Rideau rallies behind 'Return on Recogniton' with newrobust Vistance platform and proprietary Recognition Quotient"</ref>
===Vistance=== Vistance Analytics & Prescriptive Learning is a division of Rideau. Vistance Analytics analyzes the impact of recognition programs and employee perceptions on an organization's Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). Vistance Learning is a prescriptive online assessment and learning management system to help leaders improve their organization's Key Performance Indicators (KPI) through critical development, employee recognition and engagement skills.
The initial concept for Vistance was created in 2007 from a think tank of organizational psychologists and recognition experts hired by Rideau Recognition Solutions to determine whether employee recognition has a measurable impact on business outcomes.<ref name="rideau.com"/>
===Environmental Awareness=== Rideau Recognition is the first recognition firm to be certified as Carbon Neutral. The firm has been a participant and stakeholder to the United Nations Global Compact (UNCG) since 2005. Rideau has helped plant over 100,000 native trees and was the recipient of the Eterne Award in 2015.<ref name="rideau.com"/> This award is given to companies who support Tree Canada and exemplify the best in environmental stewardship.<ref>treecanada.ca</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Rodolfo Cuenca | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1928|5|1}} | birth_place = [[Manila]], [[Insular Government of the Philippine Islands|Philippine Islands]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (DEATH date then BIRTH date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Filipino | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = Chairman of the Construction and Development Corporation of the Philippines (CDCP) | notable_works = }} '''Rodolfo Cuenca''', sometimes known by his nickname, '''Rudy Cuenca''', is a Filipino businessman best known as the former chairman of the Construction and Development Corporation of the Philippines (CDCP), which is known today as the [[Philippine National Construction Corporation]].<ref name="Muego1983">{{Cite journal |last=Muego |first=Benjamin N. |date=1983-11-01 |title=The Executive Committee in the Philippines: Successors, Power Brokers, and Dark Horses |url=http://as.ucpress.edu/content/23/11/1159 |journal=Asian Survey |language=en |volume=23 |issue=11 |pages=1159–1170 |doi=10.2307/2644365 |issn=0004-4687}}</ref> He was a close associate of [[Ferdinand Marcos]], and is noted not to be embarrassed by "''his much-criticized close association with Marcos and his being tagged as a crony.''"<ref name="AmandoDoronila20100927">{{Cite news |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20100927-294524/Crony-tells-of-rivalry-in-Marcos-inner-circle |title=Crony Tells of Rivalry in Marcos Inner Circle |last=Doronila |first=Armando |date=2010-09-27 |work=Philippine Daily Inquirer |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100928103753/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20100927-294524/Crony-tells-of-rivalry-in-Marcos-inner-circle |archive-date=2010-09-28 |dead-url=Yes}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Rodolfo Cuenca was born on May 1, 1928, at the Philippine General Hospital, to Nicolas and Cristina Cuenca. He is the eldest among four children. Cuenca spent his early years in Vigan, as his father was assigned district engineer in Ilocos Sur. In 1937, the family transferred to Bulacan, where Cuenca finished his fourth and fifth grade. He continued sixth grade in Ateneo de Manila on Padre Faura, then transferred to the Intramuros campus for his seventh grade.<ref name="Dalisay2010">{{Cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/693684262 |title=Builder of bridges : the Rudy Cuenca story |last=Dalisay |first=Jose Y. |isbn=9789712724619 |location=Manila |oclc=693684262}}</ref>
During the Second World War, Cuenca withdrew from high school and worked some jobs, one of which was at the General Engineering Depot for the US Army in Malolos. In 1946, he returned to Ateneo to finish high school. He then enrolled in Far Eastern University to study commerce,<ref name="Dalisay2010"/> but soon dropped out to work as a road contractor.<ref name="Manapat1991" /> On 2 January 1948, he married Yasmin Santos, whom Cuenca met in Angat, Bulacan.<ref name="Dalisay2010" />
== Association with Ferdinand Marcos == Cuenca financially donated to Ferdinand Marcos' first presidential campaign in 1965.<ref name="Dalisay2010" /> In his second year of presidency, Marcos awarded large-scale projects to Cuenca's company, Cuenca Construction Company, which later became part of the Construction and Development Corporation of the Philippines (CDCP).<ref name=phreader>{{cite book |last1=Schirmer |first1=Daniel |title=The Philippines Reader: A History of Colonialism, Neocolonialism, Dictatorship, and Resistance |date=1987 |publisher=South End Press |isbn=9780896082755 |page=171 |edition=illustrated |url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=TXE73VWcsEEC&lpg=PA171&ots=9944UvjkvI&dq=Rodolfo%20Cuenca%20san%20juanico%20bridge&pg=PA171#v=onepage&q=Rodolfo%20Cuenca%20san%20juanico%20bridge&f=false |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> Under the Republic Act (RA) 3741, private contractors were allowed to bid for government infrastructure projects. In 1967, CDCP won government contracts to build the Manila North and South Expressways, valued in just over $16 million.<ref name="Dalisay2010" /><ref name="Manapat1991" /> The company maintained its favored treatment until the early 80s, for the benefit Cuenca and Marcos, both of whom divided and funneled commissions and kickbacks into their own pockets.<ref name="Manapat1991" />
According to Cuenca, it was in also in 1967 when he started joining Marcos to play golf, along with Robert "Bobby" Benedicto, the latter's classmate in UP Law School, and the former's close friend since the 1950s.<ref name="MartialLawMuseumCronyism">{{Cite web|url=https://martiallawmuseum.ph/magaral/the-philippines-during-the-martial-law/|title=It Takes a Village to Loot a Nation: Cronyism and Corruption|last=|first=|date=|website=Martial Law Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="Dalisay2010" /><ref name="AmandoDoronila20100929">{{cite news |last1=Doronila |first1=Amando |title=The power brokers during martial law |url=https://www.pressreader.com/philippines/philippine-daily-inquirer/20100929/283051230787608 |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=29 September 2010}}</ref> These frequent golf sessions would continue well into the Martial Law era. For Marcos' re-election campaign in 1969, Cuenca again played the role of fundraiser.<ref name="Dalisay2010" />
== Tenure as Construction and Development Corporation of the Philippines (CDCP) Chairman == Cuenca's chairmanship of Construction & Development Corporation of the Philippines (CDCP) began in 1967, and lasted until 1983.<ref name="Dalisay2010" /><ref name="Manapat1991" /> It was during this period that Cuenca acquired much of his wealth, properties, and companies.<ref name="Manapat1991" /> Between these years, CDCP experienced a rapid rise of profits, mainly through what critics called "bloated" government contracts.<ref name="Manapat1991" /> These profits then suddenly plummeted, due to accumulation of government debts and unnecessary expenses.<ref name="Manapat1991" />{{Explain|date=July 2018}}
=== CDCP Projects === Cuenca's company was involved with many projects, which were constructed at the behest of Ferdinand Marcos and his wife, [[Imelda Marcos]].<ref name="Manapat1991" /> These included the Manila North and South Luzon Expressways, the [[San Juanico Bridge]], Imelda Marcos' Manila Bay Reclamation Project, and the [[Manila Light Rail Transit System|Light Rail Transit (LRT)]].
====Manila North and South Luzon Expressways==== The first major government contract CDCP was awarded were for the construction of Manila North and South Luzon Expressways.<ref name="Manapat1991" /> By the end of 1968, the first phase of the Manila North Luzon Expressway (NLEX) was open to the public, the road measuring 28 kilometers towards Guiginto Bulacan from Balintawak. In the same year of 1968, construction for the Manila South Luzon Expressway (SLEX) began. The initial 16-kilometer stretch from Nichols to Alabang was finished by 1970.<ref name="Dalisay2010" />
These contracts also allowed CDCP to gain back their expenditures and/or capital <ref name="Dalisay2010" /><ref name="Manapat1991" /> by collecting toll fees for a decade, "starting from 1968 or until it accumulated $6.1 million, whichever came first."<ref name="Manapat1991" /> CDCP, however, requested that the duration be extended, as well the amount increased, justifying that their cost of operations had also inflated, and that they were held responsible "not only to maintain the highways but also to improve and 'expand' them."<ref name="Manapat1991" /> Although a TRB report showed evidence that CDCP has amassed $25.6 million already in one year alone from 1976–77, TRB approved their request and extended the duration to thirty years. Presidential Decrees (PD) 1112 and 1113 in 1977 also imposed an increase in toll rates, forcing the public to pay steep fees that would primarily benefit CDCP and Cuenca's pocket.<ref name="Manapat1991" /> During a 1975 toll hike, buses boycotted the NLEX and SLEX roads. The Marcos administration retaliated by releasing a PD that closed service roads for buses, which then had no choice to pass through the expressways.<ref name="Manapat1991" /><ref name="MartialLawMuseumCronyism" />
==== San Juanico Bridge ==== {{main|San Juanico Bridge}} In 1974, the Marcos administration and the CDCP tapped Japanese Official Development Assistance (ODA) loans<ref name="IBON2005">{{Cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/68191461 |title=Fifty years of Japan ODA : a critical review for ODA reform : Reality of Aid Asia-Pacific 2005 report. |date=2005 |publisher=IBON Books |isbn=9710325523 |location=Manila |oclc=68191461}}</ref> to build the [[San Juanico Bridge]], which crossed the [[San Juanico Strait]] and connected the two then-underdeveloped islands of Leyte and Samar.<ref name="RoelLandingin20080213">{{Cite web |url=http://pcij.org/stories/7-in-10-oda-projects-fail-to-deliver-touted-benefits |title=7 in 10 ODA projects fail to deliver touted benefits |last=Landingin |first=Roel R. |date=2008-02-13 |website=[[Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism]] Website |language=en-US |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012170044/http://pcij.org/stories/7-in-10-oda-projects-fail-to-deliver-touted-benefits |archive-date=2009-10-12 |dead-url=No |access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref> With a total length of {{convert|2.16|km|mi|sp=us}}, it remains the longest bridge spanning a body of seawater in the Philippines.
It was touted as President [[Ferdinand Marcos]]' "birthday gift" to his wife [[Imelda Marcos|Imelda]],and <ref name="LyzaSabornido20140917"/> it was one of the high-visibility foreign-loan projects initiated by Marcos during the run-up to the 1969 Presidential election campaign.<ref name="Manapat1991">{{Cite book |title=Some are smarter than others : the history of Marcos' crony capitalism |last=Ricardo. |first=Manapat, |date=1991 |publisher=Aletheia Publications |isbn=9719128704 |location=New York |oclc=28428684}}</ref> Completed four years later, it was inaugurated on July 2, 1973 - Imelda Marcos' birthday.<ref name="LyzaSabornido20140917">{{Cite web|url=http://faq.ph/10-facts-you-should-know-about-san-juanico-bridge-in-samar-and-leyte/|title=10 Facts You Should Know about San Juanico Bridge in Samar and Leyte|last=Sabornido|first=Lyza|date=17 September 2014|website=|publisher=FAQ.ph|access-date=26 May 2016}}</ref>
Upon its completion, economists and public works engineers tagged it as a white elephant which was "''constructed several decades too soon''",<ref name="RoelLandingin20080213"/> because its average daily traffic (ADT) was too low to justify the cost of its construction.<ref name="RoelLandingin20080213"/> As a result, its construction has been associated with what has been called the Marcoses' "''[[edifice complex]]''".<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://newslab.philstar.com/31-years-of-amnesia/building-spree|title=Edifice complex {{!}} 31 years of amnesia|last=Afinidad-Bernardo|first=Deni Rose M.|date=|website=Philstar|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref><ref name="MartialLawMuseumEdificeComplex">{{Cite news |url=https://martiallawmuseum.ph/magaral/edifice-complex-building-on-the-backs-of-the-filipino-people/ |title=Edifice Complex: Building on the Backs of the Filipino People |work=Martial Law Museum |access-date=2018-05-01 |language=en-US}}</ref>
In the decades after the Marcoses administration, economic activity in Samar and Leyte has finally caught up with the bridge's intended function, and it has become an iconic tourist attraction acknowledged as "''part of the identity of people in Samar and Leyte.''"<ref name="MartialLawMuseumEdificeComplex" />
==== Manila Bay Reclamation ==== CDCP, again at Imelda's behest sought out a land reclamation project in Manila Bay. They were to construct an artificial 240-hectare white beach behind the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]]. The rationale of the project was to create a 'Cannes' vibe for the international visitors of the Manila Film Festival. The white sand was quarried from the cities of Mariveles and Cavite. This area is now known to be the [[Bay City, Metro Manila|Manila Bay Freeport Zone]]. Also at Imelda's command, CDCP and other companies worked to create a "huge complex of native-style pavilions"<ref name="Manapat1991"/> for representatives of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in their 1979 conference in Manila.<ref name="Manapat1991" /> The complex became a ghost town throughout the 1980s.<ref name="Manapat1991" />{{Update inline|reason=Has it been repurposed since the source cited was published in 1991?|?=yes|date=July 2018}}
==== Light Rail Transit ==== Another project of the CDCP was the [[Manila Light Rail Transit System|Light Rail Transit (LRT)]], this time partly financed by a $40 million loan from the Belgian government.<ref name="Manapat1991"/> A study of the World Bank in 1977 challenged the intentions of the project, stating that Manila needed a street-level transport system, not a 'high-flyer'.<ref name="Manapat1991"/>{{elucidate|date=July 2018}} A street-level transport system would also cost much cheaper, with only a $8.1 million estimate, compared to the $278 million over-all cost for the LRT.<ref name="Manapat1991"/> Despite these skepticisms, Marcos permitted Cuenca to begin construction in October 1981.<ref name="Manapat1991"/>
==== Other projects ==== Other projects the CDCP under Cuenca handled were the [[Pantabangan Dam]], and the [[Candaba Viaduct]].<ref name=phreader/>
==== Turnover of Chairmanship to Roberto Ongpin ==== Cuenca eventually{{when|date=July 2018}} invited Roberto Ongpin to take his place as CDCP chairman,<ref name="AmandoDoronila20100929" /> although Cuenca kept his position as president, and "7% ownership" of the firm.<ref name="Manapat1991" />
== 1987 PCGG Case == On July 24, 1987, the Presidential Commission on Good Government (PCGG) filed a case whose respondents included Cuenca and his son Roberto, Imelda Marcos, Roberto Ongpin, former Philippine National Bank president Panfilo O. Domingo, Development Bank of the Philippines officer Don Ferry, and eleven others,<ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619">{{Cite news |url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2018/06/19/Supreme-Court-ill-gotten-wealth-PCGG-Ferdinand-Marcos-cronies.html) |title=SC junks PCGG's ill-gotten wealth claims vs. Marcos, cronies |last=DeGuzman |first=Chad |date=2018-06-19 |work=CNN Philippines}}</ref> claiming that the respondents had engaged in “schemes, devices or stratagems” to acquire ill-gotten wealth.<ref name="”ABSCBN20100809”">{{Cite news |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/08/09/10/gov%E2%80%99t-loses-p51-billion-claim-against-marcos-cronies |title=Gov’t loses P51 billion claim against Marcos cronies |date=2010-10-09 |work=ABS CBN News |access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> On August 5, 2010, the Sandiganbayan dismissed the case after throwing out 60 of the 100 documentary exhibits presented by the PCGG at the trial because they were photocopies, rather than original copies of the documents.<ref name="”ABSCBN20100809”" /> The 27-page decision penned by Sandiganbayan Associate Justice Alex L. Quiroz,<ref name="”ABSCBN20100809”" /> asserted that “since the due execution and authenticity of said photocopied documents had not been proved, the same were inadmissible in evidence. Further, the documents in question were rendered inadmissible as they were only photocopies.<ref name="”ABSCBN20100809”" />”
In June 2018, the Philippine Supreme Court’s First Division<ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619" /> dismissed the complaint of the PCGG against the 2010 Sandiganbayan ruling, stating that the Supreme Court was not able to review the evidence in order to rule on the PCGG’s complaint.<ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619" /> The 28-page decision penned by Supreme Court Associate Justice [[Noel Tijam]] <ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619" /> said that:<ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619" /> "In order to determine the veracity of the Republic's main contention that it has established a prima facie case against respondents through its documentary and testimonial evidence, a reassessment and reexamination of the evidence is necessary<nowiki>[….]</nowiki> Unfortunately, the limited and discretionary judicial review allowed under Rule 45 does not envision a re-evaluation of the sufficiency of the evidence upon which respondent court's action was predicated.<ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619" /> "
The PCGG released a press statement reacting to the decision, saying "Although the complaint was filed by the PCGG more than 31 years ago, and the Supreme Court decision was a mere affirmation of the Sandiganbayan ruling 8 years ago, the present officials of PCGG will still exhaust all possible legal remedies to pursue the case and to protect government interest.” <ref name="ChadDeGuzman20180619" />
== 2010 biography == In the 2000s, Cuenca sought out authors Jose Dalisay Jr. and Antonette Reyes to write his biography, which was eventually published in September 2010 under the title "''Builder of Bridges: the Rudy Cuenca Story''".<ref name="AmandoDoronila20100927" />
Journalist [[Amando Doronila]], who had himself been one of the first critics arrested when Marcos proclaimed martial law in 1972, noted that "''the book is the first time a Marcos crony or a senior functionary has written about his role in the Marcos hierarchy,''" adding that in the book, "''Rodolfo Cuenca who admits to being a Marcos crony, reveals for the first time an insider’s view of the heightening rivalry among power blocs within the Marcos inner circle as the dictator’s health started to deteriorate in 1983... The book reveals the corruption and the corrosive tensions among the Marcos’ Palace elite that contributed to its downfall during the last three years of the dictatorship.''<ref name="AmandoDoronila20100927" />"
== See also == * [[Cronies of Ferdinand Marcos]] * [[Ferdinand Marcos]]

{{ad|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Rosslyn Data Technologies (aka Rosslyn Analytics) | logo = File:Rosslyn Data Technologies logo.png | type = [[Public Limited Company]] | traded_as = {{aim|RDT}} | genre = | foundation = 2007 | founder = Charles Clark, Hugh Cox | location_city = [[London]] | location_country = [[UK]] | location = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = John O’Hara (Chairman)
Roger Bullen (CEO) | industry = [[Business Intelligence]] | products = | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 50-100 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.rosslynanalytics.com/ www.rosslynanalytics.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Rosslyn Data Technologies''' (aka '''Rosslyn Analytics''') ([[London Stock Exchange|LSE]]: [http://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-markets/stocks/summary/company-summary.html?fourWayKey=GB00BKX5CP01GBGBXASQ1 RDT]) is a software company providing data extraction, data cleansing and data enrichment technologies to clients through its cloud-based data platform. Its client base includes large enterprises, such as [[Coca-Cola Enterprises]],{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/cloud-computing/3303190/coca-cola-bottling-firm-implements-rosslyn-cloud-analytics/|title=Coca-Cola bottling firm implements Rosslyn cloud analytics|author=Leo King|work=Computerworld UK|accessdate=15 January 2015}} Xerox Business Services,{{cite web|url=http://tbrnewscommentary.wordpress.com/2012/04/23/xerox-will-expedite-its-services-led-transformation-by-investing-in-cloud-mobility-analytics-and-vertical-specific-solutions-during-2012/|title=Xerox will expedite its services-led transformation by investing in cloud, mobility, analytics, and vertical-specific solutions during 2012|work=TBR Newsroom|accessdate=15 January 2015}} [[Aberdeen Asset Management]],{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/10509550/Rosslyn-Analytics-raises-2.1m-before-New-Year-IPO.html|title=Rosslyn Analytics raises £2.1m before New Year IPO|date=11 December 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=15 January 2015}} and The [[Weir Group]]. The company is listed on [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]], a sub-market of the [[London Stock Exchange]], and is headquartered in London with offices in New York City and Chicago, Illinois. ==History== Rosslyn Analytics was founded in 2007 by Charles Clark and Hugh Cox. The company was named after [[Rosslyn Chapel]] in Midlothian, Scotland, which is famous for its mysterious carvings, believed to contain a message or even music that has never been verifiably decoded. In 2009, the company launched its first cloud-based business intelligence product - a self-service spend analytics app for its RAPid data platform. The offering won awards for innovation and excellence, including the Technology Excellence Award for “Best New Product”,{{cite web|url=http://www.bcs.org/content/conWebDoc/35191|title=2009 Technology Excellence Awards winners and medallists - 2009 winners and medallists - 2009 Awards - IT Industry Awards Archive - UK IT Industry Awards - Awards and competitions - Events - BCS - The Chartered Institute for IT|publisher=Bcs.org|accessdate=15 January 2015}} and the ICT Excellence Award for “Best Innovative Service of the Year”.{{cite web|url=http://www.midlandsbusinessnews.co.uk/West-Midlands-ICT-Excellence-Awards-2009-finalists-announced/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150118133621/http://www.midlandsbusinessnews.co.uk/West-Midlands-ICT-Excellence-Awards-2009-finalists-announced/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 January 2015|title=Midlands Business News West Midlands ICT Excellence Awards 2009 finalists announced - Midlands Business News|work=Midlands Business News|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|reason=Invites user submissions. Contact us notes "Press releases and news items submitted are reviewed as to their news value and suitability for our audience", but PR is not labeled and source is not disclosed.|date=March 2016}} In April 2011, as a public service to help the UK Government reduce the deficit by getting better control of its purchasing, Rosslyn Analytics offered to provide free spend analytics to the government in just 30 days. The government refused the offer.{{cite web|url=http://spendmatters.com/uk/rosslyn-analytics-govenrment/|title=Rosslyn Analytics p*** off the Government with procurement data analysis offer|work=Spend Matters|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In January 2012, Rosslyn Analytics entered the United States establishing offices in New York City and Denver, Colorado. Rosslyn Analytics was the first technology company to bring QlikView into the cloud in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://investor.qlikview.com/common/mobile/iphone/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=666260&CompanyID=ABEA-4QVVLE&mobileid=|title=QLIK - NASDAQ|publisher=Investor.qlikview.com|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In 2013, Rosslyn Analytics was featured in Gartner’s Magic Quadrant for Strategic Sourcing Application Suites.{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/208839487/Gartner-MQ-2013-Sourcing-Suites|title=Gartner MQ 2013 - Sourcing Suites|publisher=Scribd.com|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In February 2014, the company filed its first patent with the UK Intellectual Property Office{{cite web|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/p-pj?lastResult=50&perPage=10&startYear=2014&startMonth=April&startDay=02th+-+6515&endYear=2014&endMonth=April&endDay=02th+-+6515&filter=&sort=Publication+Date&status=undefined|title=IPO : Searchable Patents Journal|publisher=Ipo.gov.uk|accessdate=15 January 2015}} on machine-learning. In April, Rosslyn Analytics went public on AIM under the name of Rosslyn Data Technologies Group plc.{{cite web|url=http://www.iii.co.uk/research/LSE:RDT/news/item/1065958/admission-aim-and-first-day-dealings|title=ROSSLYN DATA Share News - RDT Stock News - Interactive Investor|work=Interactive Investor|accessdate=15 January 2015}}In May, Rosslyn Analytics joined the UK government’s G-Cloud 5 Framework for Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) providers.{{cite web|url=http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Rosslyn-Analytics-announce-self-service-spend/story-21147074-detail/story.html|title=Rosslyn Analytics announce self-service spend analytics solution is now free for councils|work=Western Daily Press|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In May 2015, Pricewaterhouse Coopers (PwC) partnered with Rosslyn Analytics to offer cloud-based big data services to clients.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesscloudnews.com/2015/05/05/pwc-rosslyn-partner-on-cloudy-big-data/|title=PwC, Rosslyn partner on cloudy big data {{!}} Business Cloud News|website=www.businesscloudnews.com|access-date=2018-06-12}} == Recognition == In January 2011, JMP Securities recognized Rosslyn Analytics as one of its “Hot 100” software companies to watch.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswings.co.uk/articles/Six-tech-companies-to-look-out-for|title=Six tech companies to look out for|publisher=Businesswings.co.uk|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In March 2013, Bessemer named Rosslyn Analytics as one of the top Business Intelligence / Analytics cloud companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.bvp.com/cloud|title=Cloud Computing|publisher=Bvp.com|accessdate=15 January 2015}} In December 2015, Rosslyn Analytics was named a strong performer in the Forrester Research report, “The Forrester Wave™: Cloud Business Intelligence Platforms, Q4 2015.”{{cite web|url=https://www.forrester.com/The+Forrester+Wave+Cloud+Business+Intelligence+Platforms+Q4+2015/fulltext/-/E-RES113305|title=The Forrester Wave™: Cloud Business Intelligence Platforms, Q4 2015|work=Forrester Research|accessdate=7 January 2016}} In May 2016, Rosslyn Analytics recognized as finalist for the 2016 Microsoft Data Platform Partner of the Year award https://news.microsoft.com/2016/05/31/microsoft-announces-2016-partner-of-the-year-winners-and-finalists/#k2eZjv1T1PllGIUo.97 In March 2017, Rosslyn Data Technologies was shortlisted for analytics product of the year in the UK Cloud Awards. http://ukcloudawards.co.uk/2017-shortlist == Products == The company’s flagship product is its cloud-based data platform called RAPid. RAPid provides self-service data integration, cleansing, enrichment, analysis and visualization capabilities via a single platform. Business users access the benefits of the platform via automated and manual self-service tools.{{cn|date=February 2018}} The RAPid platform comes with a number of pre-built analytical apps sold as modular [[solution]]s such as spend analytics, people analytics, forensics analytics, expense analytics and supplier performance management. ==Founders== Rosslyn Analytics was founded by Charles Clark and Hugh Cox, two former British Army officers. Charles has been recognized for his leadership by Supply & Demand Chain Executive, having been identified as a “Pro to Know” from 2010 to 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/10269268/2010-pros-to-know|title=2010 Pros to Know|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/10243158/2011-pros-to-know|title=2011 Pros to Know|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/10885560/supply-chain-pros-to-know|title=Supply Chain Pros to Know - Supply & Demand Chain Executive|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/news/10879380/supply-demand-chain-executive-announces-2013-pros-to-know-award-winners|title=Supply & Demand Chain Executive Announces 2013 "Pros to Know" Award Winners|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sdcexec.com/article/11321647/meet-ryan-verbecken-our-pro-of-the-year-as-well-as-all-the-other-men-and-women-making-a-difference-in-supply-chain|title=Meet Ryan Verbecken, our Pro of the Year, as well as all the other men and women making a difference in supply chain|work=Supply & Demand Chain Executive|accessdate=15 January 2015}} Hugh Cox is the company’s Chief Data Officer. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:British companies established in 2007]] [[Category:Business intelligence companies]] [[Category:Business software companies]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Alternative Investment Market]] [[Category:Software companies based in London]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 2007]]

{{short description|company which produces Middle Eastern-style food products}} {{Infobox company | name = Sabra Dipping Company | logo = Sabra company logo.png | type = [[Limited liability company]] | predecessor = Sabra-Blue & White Foods | foundation = {{start date and age|1986|df=yes}} (as Sabra-Blue & White Foods) | founders = Zohar Norman
Yanko family | location_city = [[White Plains, New York|White Plains]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S.{{cite news|author=Todd Wasserman|title=Sabra Hummus Breaks National Campaign|newspaper=Brandweek|date=March 3, 2009|url=http://www.brandweek.com/bw/content_display/news-and-features/packaged-goods/e3i9f08e8d32669ab32972829083aa1c13a|dead-url=y|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305120523/http://www.brandweek.com/bw/content_display/news-and-features/packaged-goods/e3i9f08e8d32669ab32972829083aa1c13a|archivedate=March 5, 2009|accessdate=September 5, 2009}} | key_people = {{plainlist| * Shali Shalit-Shoval ([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]]) * Erik Martinoli ([[Chief Financial Officer|CFO]]) * Eugenio Perrier (Chief Marketing Officer) * Stacey Zeltner (VP of [[Human Resources]]) * Frank Armetta (VP of Supply Chain) * Tulin Tuzel ([[Chief Technology Officer|CTO]]) * Meiky Tollman (Chief of Operations) }} | industry = [[Food production]] | products = [[Dip (food)|Dip]]s and [[spread (food)|spread]]s | revenue = [[United States dollar|US$]]800 million (2016) | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 500 (2014){{cite web|author1=Mark Gormis|title=Sabra Dipping Co. opens new plant expansion|url=http://www.richmond.com/business/sabra-dipping-co-opens-new-plant-expansion/article_7d6d6ea8-34d9-579b-8695-ade53328cfc5.html|publisher=Richmond Times-Dispatch, Richmond, VA|accessdate=1 November 2017|date=8 October 2014}} | parent = [[Strauss (company)|Strauss]], [[PepsiCo]] | homepage = http://www.sabra.com }} '''Sabra Dipping Company, LLC''' is a U.S.-based company which produces [[Middle Eastern cuisine|Middle Eastern-style]] and other food products, including [[hummus]], [[tzatziki]] dip, [[guacamole]], and Mediterranean [[salsa (sauce)|salsa]].{{cite web|title=Products|publisher=Sabra Dipping Company|url=http://sabra.com/index.html|accessdate=November 1, 2017}} All Sabra products are certified [[kosher]] and [[vegetarian]], and are available throughout the U.S. and Canada.{{cite web|url=http://sabra.com/about/FAQ|title=Sabra FAQ|accessdate=November 1, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151024072905/http://sabra.com/about/FAQ|archivedate=October 24, 2015|df=}}{{cite news|title=Sabra Hummus Co. Transforms Union Square Park into Mediterranean Café|newspaper=The New York Blueprint|date=September 16, 2009|url=http://sabranews.blogspot.com.au/2009/09/nyblueprint.html|accessdate=November 1, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Sabra Dipping|publisher=OK Kosher Certification|url=http://www.ok.org/consumers/kosher-food-guide/?S=Sabra+Dipping&st=|accessdate=November 1, 2015}} As of 2016, the company held a 60% market share for hummus sales in the United States, and was forecast to exceed $1 billion in sales in 2017.{{cite web|author1=Elaine Watson|title=Sabra 'well on its way' to becoming our next $1bn brand, says PepsiCo|url=https://www.foodnavigator-usa.com/Article/2016/09/29/Sabra-could-be-our-next-1bn-brand-says-PepsiCo|publisher=Foodnavigator-USA.com, William Reed Business Media|accessdate=1 November 2017|date=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|author1=Scott Goodson|title=The Surprising Rise of Hummus in America|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/scott-goodson/the-surprising-rise-of-hu_b_7520674.html|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=1 November 2017|date=5 June 2015}} ==Growth== [[File:Sabra hummus container.jpg|thumb|A container of Sabra hummus]] The company was founded in 1986 as Sabra-Blue & White Foods. The company was bought in 2005 by [[Israel]]i food manufacturer [[Strauss (company)|Strauss]]. In March 2008, Strauss entered a joint-venture partnership with [[Frito-Lay]], a division of the multinational [[PepsiCo]] corporation. Strauss owns 50% and PepsiCo 50% of the company.{{cite web|url=http://www.strauss-group.com/brand/sabra/|title=Strauss Group brands: Sabra|publisher=Strauss Group|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} In November 2008, the company announced the construction of a new $61 million plant in [[Chesterfield County, Virginia]], expected to employ 260 people and come on line in mid-2010.{{cite press release|format=PDF|title=Governor Kaine Announces Sabra Dipping Company Will Open a New Food Manufacturing Plant in Chesterfield County|publisher=Virginia's Gateway Region Economic Development Organization|date=November 19, 2008|url=http://www.gatewayregion.com/uploads/documents/11.19.08_Sabra_Dipping_Company.pdf|accessdate=September 5, 2009|}}{{cite web|title=Sabra Dipping Company, a Joint Venture Between Strauss Group and PepsiCo, Announced Plans to Open a State-of-the-art Plant in Richmond, Virginia|publisher=PRNewswire.uk|url=http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/sabra-dipping-company-a-joint-venture-between-strauss-group-and-pepsico-announced-plans-to-open-a-state-of-the-art-plant-in-richmond-virginia-152873985.html|date=November 24, 2008|accessdate=November 1, 2015}} The company grew over 50% between August 2008 and August 2009. By 2016, Sabra had gained a 60% market share of hummus in the United States, and, through its co-ownership and sales channels with [[PepsiCo]], was close to $1 billion in annual sales. To parallel the rising consumer demand for hummus, American farmers have increased their production of chickpeas four-fold since 2009, harvesting more than {{Convert|100000000|lb|kg}} in 2015, up from about {{Convert|25000000|lb|kg}} in 2009.{{cite web|author1=Justin R. Silverman|title=Hummus's quest to conquer America, one mouth at a time|url=https://www.today.com/food/hummus-quest-conquer-america-one-mouth-time-t87156|publisher=Today|accessdate=1 November 2017|date=20 April 2016}} ==Marketing== During the run-up to the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. presidential election]], Sabra commissioned sculptor Kirk Rademaker to create [[bust (sculpture)|bust]]s of candidates John McCain, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton out of 100 pounds of hummus.{{cite news|author=Theresa Howard|title=Ad Track: Winning ads really work for consumers|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/adtrack/2008-06-29-cannes-lion-winners-consumers_N.htm|date=June 30, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025082731/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/adtrack/2008-06-29-cannes-lion-winners-consumers_N.htm|archive-date=October 25, 2012}} Sabra launched its first U.S. national advertising campaign in March 2009, with the [[StrawberryFrog]] ad agency.{{cite news|author1=Amy Martinez|author2=Melissa Allison|title=Savory Moment's customers come to the aid of its founder|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=March 13, 2009|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/local-business/savory-moments-customers-come-to-the-aid-of-its-founder/|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} In May 2009, the company began a series of promotional events in which it recreated "Mediterranean villages" in 11 major U.S. cities.{{cite news|title=Sabra Takes a Mediterranean Village on Tour across North America|publisher=PR Web|date=May 19, 2009|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2009/05/prweb2430344.htm|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} By 2015, Sabra had established greater presence among American and Canadian consumers by marketing a "cultural movement" based on a desire for people to experience hummus as an old world food with new tastes close to what they already knew. ==Boycott campaigns== Until 2010, the [[Strauss (company)|Strauss Group]] stated on their English-language website that the company donates food packages to the [[Golani Brigade]] of the [[Israel Defense Forces]].{{cite news|author1=Ron Friedman|author2=Stephanie Hodes|url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Strauss-reposts-IDF-support-commitment-on-website|title=Strauss reposts IDF-support commitment on website|publisher=Jerusalem Post|date=December 14, 2010|accessdate=October 31, 2015}}{{cite web|author=Michal Toiba|url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Strauss-Group-removes-support-for-IDF-from-website|title=Strauss Group removes support for IDF from website|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=November 18, 2010|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} Activists in the [[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions]] campaign have called for boycotts of Sabra products over the donations.{{cite web|url=http://www.qconline.com/news/illinois/depaul-students-reject-ouster-hummus-brand/article_8de4c500-c138-5f4d-9c95-f8edf89bcc0c.html|title=DePaul students reject ouster hummus brand|work=Quad-Cities Online|date=May 25, 2011|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} Student groups at [[DePaul University]], [[Princeton University]], and the [[University of Ottawa]] campaigned unsuccessfully to have their schools switch to alternate brands.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.578824|title=Canadian university students launch Sabra hummus boycott|work=Haaretz.com|date=March 9, 2014|accessdate=October 31, 2015}}{{cite news|author=Tamar Lewin|title=New Subject of Debate on Mideast: Hummus|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/04/education/04hummus.html|publisher=The New York Times|date=December 3, 2010|accessdate=September 19, 2011}} ==Hummus recalls== On 8 April 2015, Sabra recalled 30,000 cases of its classic hummus after a tub in Michigan tested positive for ''[[Listeria]]''.{{cite news|author=Rachel Abrams|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/10/business/listeria-in-sabra-hummus-prompts-new-wave-of-recalls.html|title=Listeria in Sabra Hummus Prompts New Wave of Recalls|publisher=The New York Times|date=April 9, 2015|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} Inspectors with the [[Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development]] (MDARD) learned of the possible contamination by ''[[Listeria monocytogenes|L. monocytogenes]]'' after routine inspections on March 30th at a [[Kroger]] in [[Port Huron, Michigan|Port Huron]], according to MDARD spokeswoman Jennifer Holton.{{cite news|author=Robin Erb|url=http://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2015/04/08/listeria-detected-hummus/25491479/|title=Listeria detection prompts national recall by Sabra|publisher=Detroit Free Press|date=April 16, 2015|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} On 19 November 2016, Sabra voluntarily recalled multiple hummus varieties across the U.S. after ''[[Listeria]]'' was discovered at one of its manufacturing plants, though the company stated the bacteria had not been found in any of its actual products.{{cite news|author=Ralph Ellis|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/19/health/hummus-sabra-recalled|title=Sabra hummus products recalled over Listeria concerns|publisher=CNN|date=November 19, 2016|accessdate=November 19, 2016}} ==See also== * [[List of vegetarian and vegan companies]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{PepsiCo}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sabra (Company)}} [[Category:Food manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Food and drink companies of Israel]] [[Category:PepsiCo subsidiaries]] [[Category:Hummus]] [[Category:Companies established in 1986]] [[Category:1986 establishments in the United States]]
