{{Infobox person |name = Safa Abdulla Al Geabury |image = |birth_name = Safa Abdulla Al Geabury |birth_date = {{Birthdate and age|1963|06|05}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |known_for = Gambling |nationality = Swiss |residence = Geneva |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |parents = |relatives = |spouse = |children = |education = |employer = |occupation = Businessman |module = }} '''Safa Abdulla Al Geabury''' (born 5 June 1963) is a Swiss businessman who has claimed he is a [[billionaire]]. He is the owner of Safaforex S.A. (formerly Billionaire S.A.A.A.A.A) and made his money in foreign currency dealing and trading in precious stones and jewellery.
==Early life== Safa Abdulla Al Geabury was born on 5 June 1963.<ref name=comp>[http://companycheck.co.uk/director/914803964 Safa Abdulla Algeabury] Company Check. Retrieved 14 June 2015.</ref>
==Career== Al Geabury made his money in foreign currency dealing and trading in precious stones and jewellery. Safaforex S.A. (formerly Billionaire S.A.)<ref>[http://www.moneyhouse.ch/en/u/safaforex_societe_anonyme_vaduz_succursale_de_geneve_CH-660.0.185.991-6.htm Safaforex, Société Anonyme, Vaduz, succursale de Genève.] moneyhouse. Retrieved 14 June 2015.</ref> is a firm that imports and exports precious stones and jewellery.<ref>[http://www.offshorealert.com/Search.aspx?Term=Safa+Abdulla+Algeabury Safa Abdulla Algeabury.] ''[[Offshore Alert]]''. Retrieved 14 June 2015.</ref> In 2006, the Swiss authorities sought the extradition from the United States of Yu Mei Wu, a Taiwanese national, who was alleged to have fraudulently obtained jewellery worth more than US$32 million from Al Geabury.<ref>[http://www.offshorealert.com/margaret-schwartz-extradition.aspx Swiss authorities seek extradition of prominent Taiwanese alleged jewellery thief.] [[David Marchant (journalist)|David Marchant]], ''Offshore Alert'', 7 December 2006. Retrieved 14 June 2015.</ref> He was a director of Kingdom of Treasures Limited which was dissolved in 2011.<ref name=comp/>
==London== Al Geabury formerly divided his time between Geneva and London, with a home in London's exclusive [[Grosvenor Square]] and later [[Sloane Street]]. In 2015, Al Geabury was sued by The Ritz Club, located in the basement of [[The Ritz Hotel, London|The Ritz Hotel]] owned by the [[Barclay Brothers]], for £2 million after a cheque he had written to settle gambling debts incurred in 2014 in one night's play at roulette, was not honoured.<ref name=times2016/> Al Geabury has claimed that he suffers from a gambling addiction and the club should have known that and not extended him credit.<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/gambling-addict-tycoon-wants-ritz-debts-written-off-and-claims-casino-should-not-have-let-me-lose-2m-10314102.html Tycoon wants Ritz debts written off and claims: 'Casino should not have let me lose £2m'] Paul Cheston, ''[[London Evening Standard]]'', 11 June 2015. Retrieved 14 June 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3120161/Property-tycoon-refuses-pay-2-2m-debt-run-gambling-spree.html Property tycoon refuses to pay £2.2m debt run up in gambling spree at London's Ritz casino – because he claims they should have known he was an addict.] Keiligh Baker, ''Mail Online'', 11 June 2015. Retrieved 14 June 2015.</ref><ref>"Gambling addict plea", ''[[The Times]]'', 12 June 2015, p. 4.</ref><ref>[http://www.casino.org/news/ritz-club-sues-tycoon-safa-abdulla-al-geabury-over-2-million-gambling-debt Ritz Club Sues Tycoon Safa Abdulla Al Geabury Over £2 million Gambling Debt.] Samantha Beckett, Casino.org, 13 June 2015. Retrieved 15 June 2015.</ref> In July 2015, a judge ruled that Al Geabury should honour his debts, commenting that he was "the author of his own misfortunes".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/jul/31/ritz-casino-wins-2m-in-court-from-gambling-addict-billionaire Ritz casino wins £2m in court from 'gambling addict' billionaire.] Owen Bowcott, ''The Guardian'', 31 July 2015. Retrieved 3 August 2015.</ref>
In November 2015, a worldwide freezing order was imposed by a British court for £2.6 million but no money has been paid. In court proceedings in London in April 2016, for which Al Geabury was not present, he was sentenced to 10 months in jail for [[contempt of court]] for failure to settle his gambling debts which with interest and court charges have risen to £3.2 million.<ref name=times2016/>
==Wealth== In a British court in June 2015, Al Geabury accepted that his wealth, including his collection of [[Islamic art]], was in excess of $1 billion,<ref name=mirror>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/the-devil-made-it-billionaire-5968076 'The devil made me do it': Billionaire who blew millions gambling refuses to pay casino debt.] John Shammas, ''The Mirror'', 29 June 2015. Retrieved 1 July 2015.</ref> however, in court proceedings in London in April 2016, at which Al Geabury was not present, it was claimed on his behalf that the art collection was only promised by an uncle and that he does not have it. It was also said that he had no assets worth more than £20,000.<ref name=times2016>"Billionaire" gambler jailed for flouting court orders", ''The Times'', 8 April 2016, p. 13.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *http://articles.latimes.com/1988-05-13/news/mn-3278_1_30th-birthday {{DEFAULTSORT:Geabury, Safa Abdulla}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:Swiss art collectors]] [[Category:Swiss gamblers]] [[Category:Swiss expatriates in England]]

revision.text: {{Infobox airline | airline=Savanah Airlines | image= | caption= | IATA= - | ICAO=SNI | callsign=Savanahline | founded= | commenced= | ceased= | bases= | fleet_size=Included [[BAC One-Eleven]] | destinations= | headquarters=Nigeria }} '''Savanah Airlines''' was an [[airline]] based in [[Nigeria]]. ==History== On March 27, 2002 one of the airline's [[BAC One-Eleven]]s was damaged beyond repair during a storm at [[Abuja International Airport]].{{cite web |url= http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20020327-1 |last1=|first1=|title=Aviation Safety Network: Hull loss description|date=May 5, 2007|publisher=Flight Safety Foundation|deadurl=no |accessdate=June 16, 2015}} The Nigerian government set a deadline of April 30, 2007 for all airlines operating in the country to re-capitalise or be grounded, in an effort to ensure better services and safety. The airline did not meet the Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority (NCAA)’s criteria in terms of re-capitalization and does not operate services any longer.{{cite web |url= http://allafrica.com/stories/200705050045.html |last1=|first1=|title=Nigeria: Recapitalisation: FG Clears Additional 7 Airlines|date=May 5, 2007|publisher=AllAfrica|deadurl=no |accessdate=June 16, 2015}} (subscription required for access to full story) ==Code data== * [[International Air Transport Association|IATA]] Code: '''-''' * [[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]] Code: '''SNI''' * [[Airline call sign|Callsign]]: '''SAVANAHLINE''' ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Defunct airlines of Nigeria]] {{Nigeria-airline-stub}}

{{Infobox organization | name = Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry | native_name = | native_name_lang = | type = [[Chamber of commerce]] | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | formation = {{start date and age|1956}} | founder = | founding_location = Singapore | status = | purpose = To nurture a vibrant entrepreneurial culture amongst Malay/Muslim Enterprises | headquarters = | location = 15 Jalan Pinang, [[Singapore]] | coords = | membership = 650 corporate members<ref>{{cite news |title=Spanish, UK firms eyeing petroleum ventures in PH |url=https://business.mb.com.ph/2018/08/29/spanish-uk-firms-eyeing-petroleum-ventures-in-ph/ |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Manila Bulletin Business}}</ref> | membership_year = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Muhd Shamir Abdul Rahim | slogan = | mission = | formerly = Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce (SMCC) | website = {{URL|www.smcci.org.sg}} }}
The '''Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry''' (SMCCI) is a non-profit organization, established in 1956 to support the Malay/Muslim business community in Singapore.
==History== The Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SMCCI) was first established in 1956 as the Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce (SMCC) by a group of Malay/Muslim businessmen, including the first President of Singapore, [[Yusof Ishak]].<ref name="Majulah">{{cite book |last1=Rasheed |first1=Zainul Abidin |last2=Saat |first2=Norshahril |title=Majulah!: 50 Years of Malay/Muslim Community in Singapore |date=2016 |publisher=World Scientific |isbn=9814759880 |page=385 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3uixDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA385&lpg=PA385&dq=Yusof+Ishak+SMCCI&source=bl&ots=JScfDgAiKk&sig=fW9uXWy4jLUmjy2img-r8iRrZto&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwif_9W3wYDeAhWMvo8KHdUyDM0Q6AEwD3oECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=Yusof%20Ishak%20SMCCI&f=false |accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=World Scientific Series on Singapore's 50 Years of Nation-Building |url=https://www.worldscientific.com/worldscibooks/10.1142/9980 |accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> Its establishment was initially intended to look after the trading interests of the Malay/Muslim business community, however, its name was later changed to its current name in 1995 to reflect its wider scope.<ref name="Majulah"/>
In 2006, SME Centre @ SMCCI was established as a one-stop centre for local small and medium enterprises (SMEs).<ref name="Majulah2">{{cite book |last1=Rasheed |first1=Zainul Abidin |last2=Saat |first2=Norshahril |title=Majulah!: 50 Years of Malay/Muslim Community in Singapore |date=2016 |publisher=World Scientific |isbn=9814759880 |page=388 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eHzQDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA388&lpg=PA388&dq=SME+Centre+SMCCI+2006&source=bl&ots=fNjawZLqxO&sig=h-wmAIitCI2sFa-v5Q3EAaX09_o&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiE6LyP24PeAhUBXLwKHXgsCB4Q6AEwDXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=SME%20Centre%20SMCCI%202006&f=false |accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=HomeLocal startup launches app targeting gig economy |url=https://www.theedgesingapore.com/article/local-start-releases-new-mobile-app-targeting-singapore%E2%80%99s-gig-economy |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=The Edge Singapore |date=4 May 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, The SMCCI celebrated its 60th anniversary and helped set up global hub along with [[SPRING Singapore]] and [[International Enterprise Singapore]] which would identify food firms scale up their halal exports.<ref>{{cite news |title=New global hub to help scale up halal food exports |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/business/new-global-hub-to-help-scale-up-halal-food-exports |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=The Straits Times |date=22 October 2016 |language=en}}</ref>
In 2018, The SMCCI collaborated with [[Enterprise Singapore]] and One Kampong Glam Association in a project led by [[Info-communications Media Development Authority|Infocomm Media Development Authority]] to digitalize businesses within the [[Kampong Glam]] vicinity.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kampong Glam to undergo digital makeover under plan to boost retail sector |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/kampong-glam-to-undergo-digital-makeover-under-plan-to-boost-retail-sector |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=The Straits Times |date=3 November 2017 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Kampong Glam shopping belt to revive buzz with digital makeover |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/tech/kampong-glam-shopping-belt-to-revive-buzz-with-digital-makeover |work=The Straits Times |date=4 November 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
===Timeline=== * '''1956''' – The SMCC was set up in an effort to uplift the Malay/Muslim enterprises. It started out with only 15 companies, with their first office located at 500 Victoria Street.<ref name="Majulah"/> * '''1988''' – The SMCCI’s office was relocated to International Plaza.<ref>{{cite news |title=New office of Malay chamber |url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19880411-1.2.30.21 |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=The Straits Times |date=11 April 1988}}</ref> * '''1995''' – SMCC was renamed to SMCCI in order to reflect its wider scope * '''1997''' – The SMCCI’s office was relocated to 72A Bussorah Street.<ref name="Majulah"/> * '''2006''' – SME Centre @SMCCI is established.<ref name="Majulah2"/> * '''2009''' – The SMCCI’s office was again relocated to its current address at 15 Jalan Pinang. * '''2018''' – The SMCCI collaborated with Enterprise Singapore and One Kampong Glam Association in a project led by Infocomm Media Development Authority to digitalise businesses within the Kampong Glam vicinity.<ref>{{cite news |title=Grab to offer cashless payment in Kampong Glam |url=https://sbr.com.sg/information-technology/more-news/grab-offer-cashless-payment-in-kampong-glam |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=Singapore Business Review |date=12 July 2018}}</ref>
===List of Past Presidents=== * '''1956-1960''' – Mr Haji Abdul Hamid Allwie<ref name="ulangtahun">{{cite news |title=DPPMS meraikan ulang tahun ke-60 |url=https://specials.beritaharian.sg/sites/default/files/sinmalc3_0.pdf |accessdate=20 November 2018 |work=Berita Harian}}</ref> * '''1963-1966''' – Mr Salleh Basharahil<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''1968-1969''' – Mr Zainal Haji Alias<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''1970-1980''' – Mr Mohd Ghazali Gaffoor<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''1980-1984, 1988-1992, 1994-1998''' – Mr Haji Abdul Jalil Bin Haron<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''1984-1988''' – Mr Syed Ali Redha Alsagoff<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''1992-1994''' – Mr Jamil Marican<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''1999-2003''' – Mr Umar Abdul Hamid<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''2003-2005''' – Ms Nooraini Noordin<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''2005-2009''' – Dato' Mohd Zain Abdullah<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''2009-2013''' – Mr Abdul Rohim Sarip<ref name="ulangtahun"/> * '''2013-2017''' – Mr Zahidi Abdul Rahman
==Functions and activities == Since its establishment, SMCCI has played an active role in the facilitation of its members’ trade activities and acts as a point of contact between local and international sellers and consumers.<ref>{{cite news |title=Malay chamber of commerce to hold business missions |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/malay-chamber-of-commerce-to-hold-business-missions |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=The Straits Times |date=6 March 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
SMCCI collates information on business opportunities and disseminates it among its members. Like other recognised chambers of commerce, SMCCI is authorised to endorse certificates of origin as needed by exporters.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mokhtar |first1=Faris |title=Malay Chamber of Commerce endorses Tony Tan |url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/blogs/singaporescene/malay-chamber-commerce-endorses-tony-tan-171834816.html |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=Yahoo News |date=18 August 2011 |language=en-SG}}</ref> Today, SMCCI continues to work in representing the interests of the local Malay/Muslim business community and serves as a platform to create opportunities for members through regular business missions, conferences, networking sessions and activities. Now, with its subsidiary, SME Centre@SMCCI, works to strengthen capabilities and encourage local SMEs to adopt technologies and expand their business overseas.<ref>{{cite news |title=Singapore Muslim businesses out to tempt Japanese |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/singapore-muslim-businesses-out-to-tempt-japanese |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=The Straits Times |issue=Malay chamber of commerce leads 10 food and fashion companies on mission to Tokyo and Hokkaido |date=11 December 2016 |language=en}}</ref>
Since 2010, SMCCI has been hosting Malay/Muslim Business Conference for sharing industry knowledge and expertise with the participation of successfull Malay/Muslim entrepreneurs.<ref name="Majulah3">{{cite book |last1=Rasheed |first1=Zainul Abidin |last2=Saat |first2=Norshahril |title=Majulah!: 50 Years of Malay/Muslim Community in Singapore |date=2016 |publisher=World Scientific |isbn=9814759880 |page=386-387 |url=https://books.google.com.bd/books?id=eHzQDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA388&lpg=PA388&dq=SME+Centre+SMCCI+2006&source=bl&ots=fNjawZLqxO&sig=h-wmAIitCI2sFa-v5Q3EAaX09_o&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiE6LyP24PeAhUBXLwKHXgsCB4Q6AEwDXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=SME%20Centre%20SMCCI%202006&f=false |accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> In 2014, Prime minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]] and [[Yaacob Ibrahim]], the Minister for Communications and Information attended the event as the Guest of Honor and gave a speech at the conference.<ref>{{cite news |title=Transcript of Speech by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the Malay-Muslim Business Conference, 7 May 2014 |url=https://www.pmo.gov.sg/newsroom/transcript-speech-prime-minister-lee-hsien-loong-malay-muslim-business-conference-7-may |accessdate=13 October 2018 |work=Prime Minister‘s Office Singapore |date=6 November 2014 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Advancing Entrepreneurship: The Role of Malay/Muslim Institutions |url=http://www.rima.sg/commentary/advancing-entrepreneurship-the-role-of-malaymuslim-institutions/#.W8IWS2gzbIU |accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Sukhinder Singh Cassidy | image = Sukhinder_Singh_Cassidy.jpg | image_size = 220px | alt = Headshot of Sukhinder Singh Cassidy | caption = Sukhinder Singh Cassidy at Joyus | birth_date = 1970 | birth_name = Sukhinder Singh | birth_place = [[Dar es Salaam]], Tanzania | occupation = President, [[StubHub]] | spouse = Simon Cassidy | children = 3 | residence = [[Atherton, California]] | alma_mater = [[University of Western Ontario]], [[Richard Ivey School of Business]] | website = {{URL|joyus.com}} | boards = [[TripAdvisor]], J. Hilburn, [[Ericsson]] }}
'''Sukhinder Singh Cassidy''' (born '''Sukhinder Singh''' in 1970) is a technology executive and entrepreneur. She has worked at companies including [[Google]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] and [[News Corp]], [[Yodlee]] (YODL), and [[Polyvore]].<ref name="SSC Bio">{{cite web|title=theBoardlist Team|url=https://theboardlist.com/press-resources|website=theBoardlist}}</ref> In 2011, she founded JOYUS, the video shopping platform for women, and served as CEO then Chairman until 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joyus Launches V-Commerce|url=http://www.wwd.com/media-news/digital/joyus-launches-v-commerce-5201360|website=Women's Wear Daily}}</ref> Singh Cassidy is also Founder of theBoardlist.<ref name="fortune.com">{{cite web|title=Joyus' CEO has a new plan to get more women onto startup boards|url=http://fortune.com/2015/07/15/joyus-ceo-diversity-board/|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Sukhinder Cassidy was born in 1970 in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania to parents of [[Sikhism|Sikh]] descent. Her family moved to Ontario, Canada, when she was two years old. She grew up in [[St. Catharines]], in Canada's Niagara Region.<ref name="bizjournal">{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy: CEO of Polyvore's ‘appetite for change’ creates Silicon Valley success|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2010/03/22/focus4.html?page=all|website=Silicon Valley Business Journal}}</ref> Sukhinder Cassidy graduated from the [[University of Western Ontario]] and earned her H.B.A. from the [[Richard Ivey School of Business]] in 1992.
Sukhinder Cassidy was raised in an entrepreneurial family. Both of her parents were doctors and ran a medical practice for thirty years.<ref name="Inner Entrepreneur">{{cite web|title=Ex-Google exec Singh Cassidy on Joyus and facing her "inner entrepreneur"|url=http://fortune.com/2011/08/01/ex-google-exec-singh-cassidy-on-joyus-and-facing-her-inner-entrepreneur/|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early career=== Sukhinder Cassidy started her career in investment banking at [[Merrill Lynch]] in New York. She moved to the Merrill Lynch London office 1994. She then worked as an analyst for British Sky Broadcasting.<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg">{{cite web|title=The Rise of a Dealmaker|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2001-02-26/the-rise-of-a-dealmaker|website=Bloomberg|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>
In 1998, Sukhinder Cassidy moved to Silicon Valley and joined ecommerce startup [[Junglee (company)]] as Head of Business Development. Junglee was acquired by [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amazon to Buy two Companies|url=http://news.cnet.com/Amazon-to-buy-two-companies/2100-1001_3-214057.html|publisher=CNET}}</ref> Following the acquisition, Sukhinder Cassidy joined Amazon, where she led merchant business development for the first generation of Amazon marketplace. According to Bloomberg Business, she helped create "one of the company's first programs designed to deliver shoppers to merchants that carried what the buyers were looking for."<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg" />
Sukhinder Cassidy co-founded financial services platform [[Yodlee]] in 1999 with five engineering co-founders, including Schwark Satyavolu.<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg" /> and served as SVP of Sales and Business Development from 1999 to 2003. In 2014, Yodlee went public, trading under the ticker YODL.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yodlee, a Hub for Financial Apps, Raises $75 Million in I.P.O.|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/02/yodlee-a-hub-for-financial-apps-raises-75-million-in-i-p-o/|website=DealBook|publisher=New York Times}}</ref>
In 2003, Sukhinder Cassidy joined Google as the first General Manager for Google Local & Maps, and Head of Content Acquisition for Books, Library, Scholar, Shopping and Video. There she launched Google Local and Maps, with product manager [[Bret Taylor]] and a team of engineers. In 2004, she became head of Google's international operations in Asia Pacific (APAC) and Latin America (LATAM), becoming VP in 2005 and then President of APAC and LATAM in 2008. Singh-Cassidy is credited with building Google's presence across 103 countries in Asia Pacific and Latin America.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yet another Googler leaves: Singh Cassidy joins Accel Partners|url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/04/07/yet-another-googler-leaves-singh-cassidy-joins-accel-partners/|website=VentureBeat}}</ref>
In 2009, Sukhinder Cassidy left Google to become CEO-in-Residence at venture capital firm [[Accel Partners]].<ref name="Accel Release">{{cite web|title=Accel Partners Adds Google Executive Sukhinder Singh Cassidy as CEO-in-Residence|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/accel-partners-adds-google-executive-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-as-ceo-in-residence-61770492.html}}</ref> Singh Cassidy was named CEO of [[Polyvore]] in 2010,.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former Google Exec Singh Cassidy Becomes CEO of Fashion Start-up Polyvore|url=http://allthingsd.com/20100222/former-google-exec-singh-cassidy-becomes-ceo-of-fashion-start-up-polyvore/|website=All Things D|publisher=Dow Jones & Co.}}</ref>
===Joyus=== In October 2010, Sukhinder Cassidy had the idea for a new platform aimed at converging content and commerce through online video as a way to increase consumer engagement with products and drive direct purchases via the video.<ref name="Economic Times">{{cite web|title=Ex-Google honcho Sukhinder Singh Cassidy sets up video shopping online network Joyus|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-07/news/38346401_1_google-accel-partners-sukhinder-singh-cassidy|website=The Economic Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Making Shopping Social With Video: Joyus Founder Sukhinder Singh-Cassidy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/meghancasserly/2011/11/08/making-shopping-social-with-video-joyus-founder-sukhinder-singh-cassidy/|website=Forbes}}</ref> She founded JOYUS in January, 2011 in San Francisco, CA. Joyus.com launched to the public in August, 2011.<ref name="Inner Entrepreneur"/> Singh Cassidy raised $7.9 million in seed funding from Accel Partners, Harrison Metal, Joel Hyatt, Venky Harinarayan & Anand Rajaraman.<ref name="Joyus funding">{{cite web|title=Premium Video Commerce Site Joyus — Headed by Top Ex-Googler — Gets $7.9 Million in Funding|url=http://allthingsd.com/20110801/premium-video-commerce-site-joyus-headed-by-top-ex-googler-gets-7-9-million-in-funding/|website=All Things D}}</ref> In 2012, JOYUS raised a second round of funding totaling $11.5 million from Interwest and Time Warner, as well as existing investors.<ref name="Joyus second funding">{{cite web|title=Video Shopping Startup Joyus Raises $11.5 million in Second Round, Focuses on ROI of Online Retail|url=http://allthingsd.com/20130505/video-shopping-startup-joyus-raises-11-5m-in-second-round-focuses-on-roi-of-online-retail/|website=All Things D}}</ref>
JOYUS was ranked one of the "Hot 100" e-retailing websites by Internet Retailer in 2012;<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Hot 100|url=https://www.internetretailer.com/2012/11/27/shopping-video|website=Internet Retailer}}</ref> and one of the "Top 25 Ecommerce Companies to Watch" by Brand Innovators in 2013.<ref name="brandinnovators">{{cite web|title=Brand Innovators Honors West Coast With "Top 25 E-Commerce Companies to Watch" List|url=http://brand-innovators.com/blog/2013/05/08/brand-innovators-honors-west-coast-with-top-25-e-commerce-companies-to-watch-list/|website=Brand-Innovators.com}}</ref> JOYUS was a winner of the 2013 Brightcove Innovation Awards<ref>{{cite web|title=a winner of the 2013 Brightcove Innovation Awards|url=https://www.brightcove.com/en/company/press/2013-brightcove-innovation-award-winners-announced-play-2013-global-customer-conference|website=Brightcove}}</ref> and a winner of the 2013 L’Oreal Next Generation Digital Awards.<ref name="L'Oreal">{{cite web|title=Women in Digital: Class of 2013|url=http://lorealwomenindigital.com/awards/class-2013|website=L'Oreal Women in Digital|publisher=L'Oreal}}</ref> JOYUS was featured by [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] as one of the best Lifestyle shopping apps for the 2014 holiday season.
JOYUS was acquired by StackCommerce in September, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/09/29/stackcommerce-buys-joyus-to-focus-on-video-and-expand-into-fashion-shopping-and-beauty/|title=StackCommerce buys Joyus to focus on video and expand into fashion, shopping and beauty|last=Shieber|first=Jonathan|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-10-08|language=en}}</ref>
===#ChoosePossibility Project and theBoardlist=== In May 2015, Sukhinder Cassidy published an open letter, titled "Tech Women Choose Possibility", challenging the tech community to increase the rate of progress for women in the industry by leveraging its wealth of existing female talent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tech Women Choose Possibility|url=http://recode.net/2015/05/13/tech-women-choose-possibility/|website=Re/Code}}</ref> The letter was co-signed by 59 female entrepreneurs and investors. Singh Cassidy based the letter on her own experiences as a tech entrepreneur and research she conducted on 230 female founders and CEOs of tech companies.<ref>{{cite web|title=#ChoosePossibility Project|url=https://medium.com/@sukhindersinghcassidy/choosepossibility-project-90a217ff0a86#.gsuea6pjx|website=Medium}}</ref>
Sukhinder Cassidy launched [[theBoardlist]], the first initiative of the #ChoosePossibility Project, on July 15, 2015.<ref name="fortune.com"/> theBoardlist is an online marketplace that connects CEOs who are looking for board candidates with women who are peer-endorsed for private and public tech company boards. When it launched, theBoardlist included the names of over 600 women who had been endorsed by 50 investors and CEOs in the tech industry, from companies including [[Accel Partners]], [[Greylock Partners]], [[Twitter]], [[Lyft]] and Box.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Woman On Every Startup Board? Why Not, Says Ex-Google Exec|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ellenhuet/2015/07/15/a-woman-on-every-startup-board-boardlist-sukhinder-singh-cassidy/|website=Forbes}}</ref>
On October 20, 2015, theBoardlist announced that it had facilitated its first placement of a woman to the board of a private tech company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Boardlist, The Tool For Getting Women On Tech Boards, Has Its First Win|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/10/20/boardlist-the-tool-for-getting-women-on-tech-boards-has-its-first-win/|website=TechCrunch}}</ref>
As of late 2017, theBoardlist had attracted over 1,400 executives to nominate over 2,100 women for board service, and influenced over 100 board placements.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Boss: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy Is on a Mission to Get More Women on Company Boards|url=http://motto.time.com/5022322/sukhinder-singh-cassidy-sexism-tech/|website=Motto|publisher=Time, Inc.}}</ref>
In April 2018, Singh Cassidy was named the president of [[StubHub]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy Named President of StubHub|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/8290113/stubhub-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-named-president|website=Billboard|publisher=Billboard}}</ref>
==Personal life== Sukhinder Cassidy is married to Simon Cassidy, a fellow Canadian and former hedge-fund manager who runs an independent investment firm.<ref name="Inner Entrepreneur" /> The couple has three children and lives in the San Francisco Bay area.
==Organizations founded== * Yodlee<ref name="Dealmaker Bloomberg" /> * Joyus<ref name="Economic Times" /> * theBoardlist<ref name="fortune.com"/>
==Board member and advisor== Sukhinder Cassidy serves as a public board director at [[TripAdvisor]] (TRIP),<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://ir.tripadvisor.com/corporate-governance/board-of-directors|website=TripAdvisor|publisher=TripAdvisor, LLC}}</ref> [[Ericsson]] (ERIC),<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://www.ericsson.com/thecompany/corporate_governance/board_of_directors/members_of_the_board|website=Ericcson}}</ref> and [[Urban Outfitters]] (URBN).<ref>{{cite web|title=URBN Appoints a New Member to the Board of Directors|url=http://investor.urbn.com/news-releases/news-release-details/urbn-appoints-new-member-board-directors-and-announces|website=Urban Outfitters|publisher=Urban Outfitters, Inc.}}</ref> She previously served on the boards of [[J. Crew]] Group, Inc.(JCG), StitchFix, and as an advisor to [[Twitter]].<ref name="SSC Bio" />
==Honors== * Named one of the Most Creative People in Business by Fast Company (2017)<ref>{{cite web|title=The Most Creative People in Business|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/most-creative-people-community/c/1|website=Fast Company|publisher=Mansueto Ventures, LLC}}</ref> * Named one of the "Silicon Valley 100" by Business Insider (2016, 2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=Silicon Valley 100|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/silicon-valley-100-2016-6/#75-sukhinder-singh-cassidy-26|website=Business Insider|publisher=Business Insider Inc.}}</ref> * Named a "Power Women" by Forbes (2014)<ref name="Forbes Power Women">{{cite web|title=The Power Women Who Are Reinventing The Way You Shop Fashion Online|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carolinehoward/2014/05/28/the-power-women-who-are-reinventing-the-way-you-shop-online/|website=Forbes}}</ref> * Featured in book, ''Good Leaders Learn: Lessons from Lifetimes of Leadership'' (2013)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Seijts|first1=Gerard|title=Good Leaders Learn : Lessons from Lifetimes of Leadership|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0415659772|pages=186–195}}</ref> * Named one of "The Silicon Valley 100" by Business Insider (2012)<ref name="Business Insider 100">{{cite web|title=The Silicon Valley 100|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-silicon-valley-100-2012-1#93-sukhinder-si|website=Business Insider}}</ref> * Named one of "44 Female Founders Every Entrepreneur Should Know" (2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=44 Female Founders Every Entrepreneur Should Know|url=http://mashable.com/2012/08/06/female-founders/|website=Mashable}}</ref> * Named one of "14 Incredible Women to Watch in Silicon Valley" (2012)<ref>{{cite web|title=14 Incredible Women to Watch in Silicon Valley|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/14-incredible-women-to-watch-in-silicon-valley-2012-2?op=1|website=Business Insider}}</ref> * Included in Ad Age list of "Women to Watch" (2010)<ref name="Ad Age">{{cite web|title=Women to Watch: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-women-to-watch-2010/women-watch-2010-sukhinder-singh-cassidy/144240/|website=Ad Age}}</ref> * Selected as TechFellow Awards’ first General Management Fellow in recognition of outstanding innovation in General Management (2009)<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh|url=http://www.techfellows.com/general-management/2009/sukhinder-singh-cassidy/|website=TechFellow Awards}}</ref> * Named by Fortune as one of "tech's next-gen leaders" and featured on the cover of the annual ''Most Powerful Women'' Magazine addition (2008)<ref>{{cite web|title=My tech 'a-ha' moment: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://archive.fortune.com/galleries/2008/fortune/0809/gallery.mpw_valleygirls_qs.fortune/8.html|website=Fortune}}</ref>
==Notable Speaker== * Keynote Speaker, Dreamforce 2016<ref>{{cite web|title=Dreamforce Keynotes|url=https://www.salesforce.com/dreamforce/DF16/keynotes-cassidy/|website=Dreamforce|publisher=Salesforce.com, Inc.}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, Retail Council of Canada, Store 2015<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy|url=http://www.storeconference.ca/speakers/sukhinder-singh|website=Store Conference|publisher=Retail Council of Canada}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker at IRCE 2014 – Internet Retailer Conference & Exhibition<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, Chairman and Founder, Joyus|url=http://www.marketingsherpa.com/irce/videos/sukhinder-cassidy.php|website=Marketing Sherpa}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, D2C Convention 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukhinder Singh Cassidy Named Keynote Speaker for 2014 ERA D2C Convention|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/sukhinder-singh-cassidy-named-keynote-speaker-for-2014-era-d2c-convention-1927433.htm|website=Market Wired|publisher=Marketwire}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, Stanford University's Entrepreneurship Thought Leadership Series, 2012<ref>{{cite web|title=Find Your Vector of Impact|url=http://ecorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=2896|website=Stanford University Entrepreneurship Corner}}</ref> * Keynote Speaker, SVB CEO Summit West, 2012<ref>{{cite '''Thomas Svanikier''' (born January 1960{{Cite web|title = Mr Thomas Svanikier Director Profile - Endole|url = http://www.endole.co.uk/profile/1327057/thomas-svanikier|website = www.endole.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-08-20}}) is a leading [[Ghana]]ian entrepreneur, industrialist, and philanthropist. He is the founder and executive chairman of Svani Group, an automotive conglomerate, as well as a founder and Chairman of the Advisory Board of Fidelity Bank, a growing international financial institution. Svanikier has been at the forefront of Ghana’s economic modernization over the past 25 years, most notably in the automobile and financial sectors. ==Business story== Thomas Svanikier’s first venture was an automotive import business. Svani Limited, established in 1990, supplied Russian-made Lada cars to Ghanaian industry, NGOs and government agencies, and consumers throughout West Africa. In response to the notable absence of North American automobiles, Svani Limited reintroduced Ford and Lincoln Mercury cars to the Ghanaian market in 1994. Svanikier quickly expanded his company and renamed it Svani Group. The company imports vehicles, leases, rents and sells cars, and is a distributor of generators and other heavy-duty equipment throughout West Africa.{{Cite web|url = http://www.svanigroup.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=section&layout=blog&id=4&Itemid=54|title = About Svani Limited|date = |accessdate = 24 August 2015|website = Svani Limited|publisher = |last = |first = }} Svani has sold armored vehicles to the Office of the President of Ghana, the U.S. Secret Service in Nigeria, the Governor of Lagos State, and the governments of Liberia and Togo. The group also provides automotive maintenance and specialized equipment to the U.S. Department of State in Ghana.{{Cite web|url = http://government-contractors.insidegov.com/l/555873/Svani-Ltd-in-Accra|title = Svani Ltd. in Accra - Contracting Profile|date = |accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = InsideGov.com|publisher = Graphiq, Inc.|last = |first = }} Svani currently controls about 20% of the global vehicles market in Ghana and has service centers in Accra, Takoradi, Koforidua and Kumasi. Svani is also the sole importer and distributor of Mahindra vehicles, as well as the largest distributor of Toyota Land Cruisers and Ford vehicles in Ghana. In partnership with Svanikier’s company, Mahindra built a motorcycle and pickup truck assembly plant in Accra, Ghana.{{Cite web|url = http://artismc.com/index.php/news/article/view/54/988/|title = Mahindra to open auto assembly plant in Ghana|date = 12 August 2013|accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = Artis.com|publisher = Artis Management Consultants Private Limited|last = |first = }} The two companies are currently working on the development of a 9.6 acre car assembly and servicing center along the Accra-Tema motorway.{{cite web|last1=Obour|first1=Samuel K.|title=Svani Motors to establish vehicle assembly plant|url=http://graphic.com.gh/business/business-news/9878-svani-motors-to-establish-vehicle-assembly-plant.html|website=Graphic Online|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=8 August 2013}} A number of Svani-distributed vehicles have received nominations in Ghana’s Auto Awards.{{cite web|title=Nominees|url=http://www.ghanaautoawards.com/nominees|website=Ghana Auto Awards|accessdate=28 August 2015}} Svanikier ventured into private equity with the creation of Africa Capital LLC, which invests in transportation, energy, finance, and real estate projects. As a result, Svanikier is well known in Ghana as a job creator and investor responsible for a significant portion of the economic expansion and modernization between the 1980s and late 2000s.{{Cite book|title = Key events in African history : a reference guide|last = Falola|first = Toyin|publisher = Greenwood Press|year = 2002|isbn = 9780313361227|location = Westport, Conn.|pages = 321}} In 2010, Africa Capital’s energy subsidiary, Atholl Energy, was lauded by then President John Evans Atta Mills for its joint project with the Siemens group to construct a 180-megawatt power generation plant that greatly augmented Ghana’s power supply.{{cite web|title=President lauds Siemens, Atholl power project|url=http://edmingle.blogspot.com/2010/12/president-lauds-siemens-atholl-power.html|website=Mingle's base|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=13 December 2010}} Africa Capital is the largest shareholder of Fidelity Bank in both Ghana and Malaysia. Fidelity is currently the fourth largest bank in Ghana, and is growing rapidly. Fidelity Bank has 98 branches in Ghana and plans to increase that number significantly in the coming years.{{cite news|last1=Dzawu|first1=Moses|title=Rothschild-Backed Fidelity of Ghana to Double Branches|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-09-01/rothschild-backed-fidelity-of-ghana-to-double-branches|accessdate=28 August 2015|work=BloombergBusiness|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=2 September 2014}} In December 2014, the bank’s total assets also stood at GHC 3.135 billion. In July 2015, Svanikier and his wife were invited to be part of U.S. President Barack Obama’s delegation during his official visit to Kenya. Svanikier was also asked to take part in the Global Entrepreneurship Summit organized in Nairobi, Kenya by the U.S. Department of Commerce, at which the president met with leading figures in African business circles. As of 2015, Svanikier serves as the senior adviser for Africa for the Transnational Strategy Group,{{cite web|title=The Transnational Strategy Group Team|url=http://transnationalstrategy.com/team/|website=Transnational Strategy Group|accessdate=28 August 2015}} a Washington, D.C.-based{{Cite web|url = http://transnationalstrategy.com/contact/|title = Contact - Transnational Strategy Group|date = |accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = Transnational Strategy Group|publisher = |last = |first = }} company that provides consultancy services for governments and companies on economic and political issues.{{Cite web|url = http://transnationalstrategy.com/|title = Transnational Strategy Group - Home|date = |accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==Portfolio== Svanikier is the co-founder and chairman of several companies: * Africa Capital Ltd., a financial firm * DreamOval Ltd., an internet security technology start-up specializing in data science, enterprise software and cloud services{{Cite web|url = http://www.dreamoval.com/about/|title = About Us - DreamOval|date = |accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = DreamOval|publisher = |last = |first = }} * Atholl Energy Ltd., an energy company * Global Strategic Ventures Ltd., an armored vehicle and security company (Svanikier is also a director of the company{{Cite web|url = https://www.duedil.com/director/906177304/thomas-svanikier|title = Mr Thomas Svanikier, Director Profile at Svani Limited|date = |accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = DueDil|publisher = DueDil Ltd.|last = |first = }}) Svanikier is Chairman of the Board of Fidelity Bank in both Ghana and Malaysia. Fidelity is one of the fastest growing banks in Ghana – over the past eight years it has created 95 branches throughout the country.{{Cite web|url = http://www.fidelitybank.com.gh/media/photos/OIL__GAS.pdf|title = Energy, Oil & Gas Services|date = |accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = Fidelity Bank|publisher = |last = |first = }} Fidelity Bank has 51 branches in Ghana and plans to increase that number to 100 by the year 2017.{{Cite news|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-09-01/rothschild-backed-fidelity-of-ghana-to-double-branches|title = Rothschild-Backed Fidelity of Ghana to Double Branches|last = Dzawu|first = Moses|date = 2 September 2014|work = BloombergBusiness|access-date = 24 August 2015|via = }} Fidelity also provides the financing for Ghanaian customers to purchase or lease Mahindra vehicles produced in Svanikier's Accra plant.{{Cite web|url = http://www.automotivesupplychain.org/news/618/15/Mahindra-and-Svani-Motors-build-assembly-plant-in-Ghana/|title = Mahindra and Svani Motors build assembly plant in Ghana|date = 13 August 2013|accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = Automotive Supply Chain|publisher = Three 6 Zero Limited|last = |first = |location = London}} Additionally, he is a founding member of the American Chamber of Commerce in Ghana. ==Philanthropy== {{Quote box |width = 21.5em |border = 1px |align = |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quoted=yes |quote = It is really gratifying to see organizations like Svani step up and join the fight against Ebola.The response needs equipment, logistical support, technology and innovation and this partnership is going to boost the UN’s efforts to end this horrible disease. |salign = right |source = — Dominic Sam
UNDP Country Director in Accra[http://www.gh.undp.org/content/ghana/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2014/12/18/svani-group-joins-private-sector-effort-to-combat-ebola.html "Svani Group joins private sector effort to combat Ebola"]. United Nations Development Programme. 18 December 2014. Retrieved 20 August 2015. }} Svanikier is a well-known philanthropist in Ghana. He serves as a leader for the Opportunities Industrialisation Centre (also known as OIC International). OIC is a non-profit group in Pennsylvania that gives technical and vocational skills training to underprivileged adults and teenagers.{{Cite web|title = About Us {{!}} OIC International|url = http://www.oici.org/about-us/|website = www.oici.org|accessdate = 2015-08-20}} He is also a leader of the Africa Poverty Eradication Commission located in Accra. Svanikier is known as a generous supporter of education and youth development programs, and has donated a 35-seat bus worth $64,000 to Ghana’s renowned Winneba Youth Choir.{{cite web|title=Svani Group Donates Bus To Winneba Youth Choir|url=http://edmingle.blogspot.com/2015/03/svani-group-donates-bus-to-winneba.html|website=Mingle's base|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=9 March 2015}} He is also an ongoing benefactor of the Presbyterian Schools in the Accra neighborhood of Osu. He funded the installation of its clean water and sanitation systems, as well as the construction of its Primary School for girls and a modern library with a computer laboratory. The Girls’ School facilities are dedicated to the memory of his late mother, Agnes Federica Svanikier. In December, 2014, in the midst of the [[Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa|Ebola outbreak in West Africa]], Svani Group partnered with the [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP) in the fight against the Ebola epidemic. Svani Group donated eight heavy-duty vehicles as well as several power generators to the United Nation’s Ebola Emergency Response.{{Cite web|url = http://reliefweb.int/report/sierra-leone/svani-group-joins-private-sector-effort-combat-ebola|title = Svani Group joins private sector effort to combat Ebola|date = 18 December 2014|accessdate = 20 August 2015|website = ReliefWeb|publisher = United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|last = Owusu|first = Bossman}} In 2015, Svanikier and his wife founded the Svanikier Public Policy Leadership Initiative, which donated $100,000 to the University of Oxford’s School of Government.{{cite web|title=Fidelity Bank {{!}} Board of Directors|url=http://www.fidelitybank.com.gh/who-we-are/board-of-directors/?d=31|website=Fidelity Bank|accessdate=28 August 2015}} The funds went towards sponsorship for six Ghanaian public officials to attend courses at the University focused on Governance and Natural Resource management. ==Personal== Svanikier is a descendent of a Danish family that settled in Christiansburg, Osu, in Accra.{{Cite web|title = Goodman AMC: THOMAS SVANIKIER|url = http://goodmanamc.blogspot.com/p/thomas-svanikier-43-0million-executive.html|accessdate = 2015-08-20}} Svanikier is married and has a son and two daughters. His wife, [[Johanna Odonkor Svanikier]], was a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright Scholar]] who studied at Oxford and [[Harvard University|Harvard Universities]]. Johanna Odonkor-Svanikier is currently Ghana’s Ambassador to France, Portugal and [[UNESCO]].{{Cite web|title = Home - Ghana Embassy, Paris|url = http://paris.embassy.gov.gh/|website = paris.embassy.gov.gh|accessdate = 2015-08-20}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.fidelitybank.com.gh Fidelity Bank Ghana Limited] * [http://www.dreamoval.com DreamOval Limited] * [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=41355092 Africa Capital Limited] profile on ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Svanikier, Thomas}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ghanaian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ghanaian philanthropists]]

{{Orphan|date=March 2011}}
The '''Williamson trade-off model''' is a theoretical model in the [[economics]] of [[industrial organization]] which emphasizes the trade-off associated with [[horizontal merger]]s between gains resulting from lower [[marginal cost|costs of production]] and the losses associated with higher [[price]]s due to greater degree of [[monopoly power]].<ref>Robert Beynon, [https://books.google.com/books?id=26m3RXKUuQIC&pg=PA349&lpg=PA349&dq=Williamson+trade+off+model&source=bl&ots=2EzE7a9bfw&sig=B1AVpfWqnzC70fm35GJso3iNedQ&hl=en&ei=TGJNS--gM5X2NYWx2O4M&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CCkQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade%20off%20model&f=false "The Routledge critical dictionary of global economics"], Taylor & Francis, 1999, p. 349</ref>
The model was first presented by [[Oliver Williamson]] in his 1968 paper "Economies as an Antitrust Defense: The welfare tradeoffs" in the ''[[American Economic Review]]''.<ref>Williamson, Oliver, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1831653 "Economies as an Antitrust Defense: The welfare tradeoffs"], The ''American Economic Review'', Vol. 58, No. 1 (March 1968), pp. 18–36</ref> Williamson argued that ignoring efficiencies that may result from proposed mergers in antitrust law "fail[ed] to meet the basic test of economic rationality".<ref>Katalin Judit Cseres, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ov6Vr9ev57MC&pg=PT32&lpg=PT32&dq=Williamson+trade+off+model&source=bl&ots=e3EjP3DuHN&sig=2pKrldsGbpaPlwTodsQoWzSlpjo&hl=en&ei=mmVNS9ehCJT4NY2wgOoM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CB4Q6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20&f=false "Competition law and consumer protection"], Kluwer Law International, 2005, p. 139</ref>
[[Image:WilliamsonTOmodel.JPG|thumb|300px|Graphical illustration of the Williamson trade-off model]]
==Basic idea of the model==
Suppose that a given industry is initially characterized by [[perfect competition]] and has a constant unit cost of production equal to ''c1'' (assumed the same across all firms in the industry). Because of competition, the market price of the good produced will be equal to this unit cost, which means that firms in the industry earn [[normal profit]]s, as captured by the [[producer surplus]] (the area below the market price, but above the supply/unit cost curve).<ref name=AnP/>
Suppose further that after a merger between firms in the industry takes place, unit costs fall to ''c2<c1'' as a result of [[economies of scale]] or other forms of [[synergy]]. However, the industry is now less competitive, with a [[monopoly]] being the most extreme example. Since the firm is no longer a [[price-taking|price taker]], the price it charges will be above the (now lower) unit cost. For a monopoly, for example, the price will be set where the unit/marginal cost intersects [[marginal revenue]]. This means that the amount of [[consumer surplus]], the area below the demand curve and above the price, will be lower.<ref name=AnP/>
The change in overall [[social surplus]] of the market depends on whether the increase in producer surplus due to lower production costs is larger or smaller than the fall in consumer surplus due to higher prices. Note that it is theoretically possible that the fall in unit costs due to the merger could be sufficiently large that the post merger monopoly price ends up being lower than the pre merger competitive price in which case both producer and consumer surplus would increase. In that situation no trade-off exists and the merger is unambiguously beneficial to all market participants. More generally however, a horizontal merger can involve both costs and benefits.<ref name=AnP/>
==Applications in antitrust policy==
One implication of the Williamson model is that the gains from cost reduction do not have to be "large" in order to outweigh the losses that result from higher prices.<ref name=AnP/> This is because the welfare losses associated with the latter tend to be "second-order" (graphically, they are triangles), while the gains tend to be "first-order" (rectangles). What this means is that the gains from the merger would have to be very small, or alternatively, the demand for the good in question would have to be relatively quite [[Price elasticity of demand|inelastic]] for social surplus to decrease.<ref name=AnP/>
A broader conclusion of the model is that [[Competition law|antitrust]], or competition, policy should be "discretionary".<ref name=CLP>C. L. Pass, Bryan Lowes, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ffoNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA177&lpg=PA177&dq=Williamson+trade-off+model&source=bl&ots=QlHt5pe8fZ&sig=mPH4gLVvdECPF4N0agXsdwZ5sZE&hl=en&ei=3G9KS63OOoe0tgf1l9nkDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade-off%20model&f=false "Business and microeconomics: an introduction to the market economy"], Routledge, 1994, p. 175-178</ref> That is, government regulators who are faced with a proposed merger need to examine each proposal on a case by case basis. In some instances, the cost savings might make it worth the loss of competition, while in others they will not. This is in contrast to a "non-discretionary" policy where regulators set certain standards that any industry must meet - for example, that no firm has more than 20% market share. Then, they do not actually examine the potential gains or losses to consumer or producer surplus from a proposed merger, but only its impact on meeting the set standard - for example, whether or not the merger will increase a single firm's market share above 20%.<ref name=CLP/>
The model has been applied to the study of mergers in the US rail freight industry and the US food industry, among others.<ref>Ivaldi, Marc and McCullough, Gerard, [http://www.cepr.org/pubs/new-dps/dplist.asp?dpno=5000 "Welfare Trade-Offs in US Rail Mergers"], Centre for Economic Policy Research</ref><ref>Sanjib Bhuyan, [http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/20469/1/sp01bh01.pdf "Impact of Vertical Mergers on Food Industry Profitability: An Empirical Evaluation"]</ref> It has also been used in evaluation of actual antitrust laws by American legal scholar and judge [[Robert Bork]].<ref name=Fink>Richard Fink, [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119536139/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0 "General and partial equilibruim theory in Bork's antitrust analysis"], paper delivered at the Annual Western Economic Association International Conference, Las Vegas, Nevada, June 24–28, 1984</ref> A regulatory approach based on the model was popular in the United States in the 1980s and influenced much antitrust legislation.<ref>Patrick A McNutt, "Signalling, Strategy and Management Type" [http://www.patrickmcnutt.com/docs/Chapter%207%20Antitrust%20And%20Public%20Policy.pdf Chapter 7, Antitrust & Public Policy]</ref>
==Criticisms and limitations==
#The "trade-off" in the Williamson model involves a gain in producers' (firms') surplus and a loss in consumers' surplus. Thus, in focusing the analysis on total surplus, it neglects distributional issues and treats changes in both consumers' and producers' welfare symmetrically. However, anti-trust policy as actually practiced in many countries ([[Europe]], [[Canada]] and [[United States|US]]) appears to have the goal of maximizing consumer surplus (or this goal is stated explicitly).<ref name=Zulfi>S. Zulfi Sadeque, Competition Bureau, Industry Canada, Government of Canada, [http://www.apeccp.org.tw/doc/Workshop/w1996/doc8.htm "Some Aspects of Competition Policy: the View from Canada"], APEC Workshop on Competition Policy and Deregulation, August 17–18, 1996</ref> In that sense, as long as the post-merger market price is higher than pre-merger, the fact that producer surplus and firm profits rise is immaterial from the point of view of the regulators. In that case, only those mergers in which the fall in unit cost is sufficiently large to ensure a lower price after the merger should be permitted.<ref name=AnP>Michael Whinston in Mark Armstrong, Robert Porter, eds. [https://books.google.com/books?id=bvrn72h8dDwC&pg=PT449&lpg=PT449&dq=Williamson+trade-off+model&source=bl&ots=suaMKWbVit&sig=7NbiL-LKBviWCutjwAFTGPGD88U&hl=en&ei=3G9KS63OOoe0tgf1l9nkDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCEQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade-off%20model&f=false "Handbook of industrial organization, Volume 3"], Elsevier, 2007, p. 2373-2375</ref> For this reason, the Williamson model is not applicable in [[European Community competition law]] and is controversial in Canada.<ref name=Monti>Giorgio Monti, [https://books.google.com/books?id=hHe2PklOqPUC&pg=PT292&lpg=PT292&dq=Williamson+trade+off+model&source=bl&ots=hJXOk9GH_P&sig=P5OnAH62CPCxHSLGDN97qysclZY&hl=en&ei=FmNNS7e4KInUM-W-9fcM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CBIQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade%20off%20model&f=false "EC competition law"], Cambridge University Press, 2007, p. 292</ref> #The simplest version of the model compares a situation where initially the market is competitive to a situation where the post-merger market is not. However, if initially price exceeds marginal cost (i.e. the market is not competitive), further increases in price have a "first order" effect on consumer surplus (graphically, they are trapezoids).<ref name=AnP/> #The model is limited in that it only considers the effect of the merger on price charged by the firm(s). However, in most real life situations, firms compete on many other aspects other than price, for example product quality, capacity, research and development, and product differentiation. These variables are also likely to be affected by a merger and the basic model does not capture these effects. However, the model can and has been extended in these directions by more recent work.<ref name=AnP/> #The model ignores the possibilities that the same cost reductions and efficiency gains (once technologically feasible) may arise on their own due without any need for a merger,<ref name=Paddy>Paddy McNutt, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qZTdn1JtFV4C&cd=1e "Law, economics and antitrust: towards a new perspective"], Edward Elgar Publishing, 2005, p. 221</ref> for example via own-firm investment.
